entry.title: Efficient ReliK 3 Parallel For Loop
entry.content:
This week, I am mainly working on parallelization of enumerating xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤x_{h'r't'}xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚Äã: for u,v in nx.DiGraph(M).subgraph(subgraph).edges().

Target Code

üò≠First Try: ThreadPoolExecutor

On Countries, for each subgraph it takes around 3000 ms, while on SmallcodeX, it takes around 120 s per subgraph.

Resultüò©

This approach is definitely negative optimization.

‚ùåABORTED.

üò≠Second Try: Parallelization on GPU

Then try to do parallelization using PyTorch + CUDA.

Resultüò¢

However, it seems that there is no speed up in the experiment, for some different num_parallel values. I suspect that it is executed sequentially. Maybe I have not thoroughly understood the code.

üòÉThird Try: multiprocessing

Idea is straight forward.

I have num_processors processors. Then I partition the edges list(nx.DiGraph(M).subgraph(subgraph).edges()) into num_processors parts.

Each processor is responsible for a corresponding part.

I need to write the method process_edges_partition outside to process each part.

Experimentü§©

I ran experiment on dataset Countries and CodexSmall respectively.

We want to speed up the process for calculating ReliK scores.

Setting

Set num_processors = 10;

Using TransE embeddings.

Dataset - Countries

python experiment_controller.py -d Countries -e TransE -t ReliK

For raw implementation, it takes around 470 seconds.

For multiprocessing optimization, it takes around 123 seconds.

Speedup: Around 3.8x

Dataset - CodexSmall

python experiment_controller.py -d CodexSmall -e TransE -t ReliK

For raw implementation, it takes around 12900 seconds = 215 minutes ‚âà 3.58 hours.

For multiprocessing optimization, it takes around 1610 second ‚âà26.8 minutes‚ùóüëç

Speedup: Around 8.0x

Staying up debugging until 2:30 a.m. finally paid off.üòé

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 2 PROP Fair Clustering
entry.content:
Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering by Chen et al.

Abstract

nnn points, kkk centers.

Proportionality: any n/kn/kn/k points are entitled to form own cluster if there is another center that is closer in distance for all n/kn/kn/k points.

Clustering with no justified complaints from any subset of agents.

Tradeoff between proportional solutions and kkk-means objective.

Introduction

In centroid clustering, we want to partition data into kkk clusters by choosing kkk centers and then matching points to one of the centers.

Each data point represents a individual. We with the clustering to be fair. These agents prefer to be clustered accurately.

A clustering is fair if it respects the entitlements of groups of agents: a subset of agents is entitled to choose a center for themselves if they constitute a sufficiently large fraction of the population w.r.t. the total number of clusters. No priori knowledge about which points should be protected.

Preliminaries

N\mathcal NN data points, ‚à£N‚à£=n|\mathcal N|=n‚à£N‚à£=n.

M\mathcal MM feasible cluster centers, ‚à£M‚à£=m|\mathcal M|=m‚à£M‚à£=m.

For i,j‚ààM‚à™Ni,j\in\mathcal M\cup\mathcal Ni,j‚ààM‚à™N, we have distance (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) satisfying the triangle inequality.

Open a set X‚äÜMX\subseteq\mathcal MX‚äÜM of ‚à£X‚à£=k|X|=k‚à£X‚à£=k centers, and then match all points in N\mathcal NN to the closest center in XXX.

For a particular solution XXX and agent i‚ààNi\in\mathcal Ni‚ààN, let Di(X)=min‚Å°x‚ààXd(i,x)D_i(X)=\min_{x\in X}d(i,x)Di‚Äã(X)=minx‚ààX‚Äãd(i,x). A good clustering solution XXX will have small values of Di(X)D_i(X)Di‚Äã(X).

Different measures, different objectives:

  • kkk-median: ‚àëi‚ààNDi(X)\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)‚àëi‚ààN‚ÄãDi‚Äã(X)
  • kkk-means: ‚àëi‚ààN(Di(X))2\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}(D_i(X))^2‚àëi‚ààN‚Äã(Di‚Äã(X))2
  • kkk-center: max‚Å°i‚ààNDi(X)\max_{i\in\mathcal N}D_i(X)maxi‚ààN‚ÄãDi‚Äã(X)

Individuals prefer to be closer to their center in terms of distance.

üìñDefinition 1. Let X‚äÜMX\subseteq\mathcal MX‚äÜM with ‚à£X‚à£=k|X|=k‚à£X‚à£=k. S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN is a blocking coalition against XXX if ‚à£S‚à£‚â•‚åànk‚åâ|S|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚à£S‚à£‚â•‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ and ‚àÉy‚ààM\exist y\in\mathcal M‚àÉy‚ààM s.t. ‚àÄi‚ààS,d(i,y)<Di(X)\forall i\in S,d(i,y)\lt D_i(X)‚àÄi‚ààS,d(i,y)<Di‚Äã(X). X‚äÜNX\subseteq \mathcal NX‚äÜN is proportional if there is no blocking coalition against XXX.

ÈòªÂ°ûËÅîÁõüÔºöÂ≠òÂú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÄôÈÄâ‰∏≠ÂøÉÁÇπ yyyÔºåÂ≠òÂú®‰∏ÄÁªÑÊï∞ÊçÆÁÇπ SSS Êª°Ë∂≥ÂÖ∂ÁÇπÊï∞Ë¶ÅÊØîÁ∞áÂπ≥ÂùáÁÇπÊï∞Â§öÔºö‰ΩøÂæó SSS ‰∏≠‰ªªÊÑè‰∏ÄÁÇπÂà∞ yyy ÁöÑË∑ùÁ¶ªÔºåÈÉΩÊØîËøôÁªÑÊï∞ÊçÆÁÇπÂà∞ÂéüÊù•ÂàÜÈÖçÁöÑÂØπÂ∫îÁ∞á‰∏≠ÂøÉÁÇπÁöÑË∑ùÁ¶ªËøë„ÄÇ

ÊØî‰æãÂÖ¨Âπ≥Ôºö‰∏ÄÁªÑÁ∞áÂàÜÈÖç‰∏≠‰∏çÂåÖÂê´ÈòªÂ°ûËÅîÁõüÔºåÂàôËØ•Á∞áÂàÜÈÖçÊòØÊØî‰æãÂÖ¨Âπ≥ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

Equivalently, XXX is proportional if ‚àÄS‚äÜN\forall S \subseteq N‚àÄS‚äÜN with ‚à£S‚à£‚â•‚åànk‚åâ|S| \ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚à£S‚à£‚â•‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ and for all y‚ààMy \in My‚ààM, there exists i‚ààSi \in Si‚ààS with d(i,y)‚â•Di(X)d(i, y) \ge D_i(X)d(i,y)‚â•Di‚Äã(X).

‚ùóThe quantification is over all subset of sufficient size. Do not consider a single i‚ààSi\in Si‚ààS and ignore all of the other points.

Advantages of PROP

  • PROP implies weak Pareto optimality: For any PROP solution XXX, there does not exist another solution X‚Ä≤X'X‚Ä≤ s.t. Di(X‚Ä≤)<Di(X)D_i(X')\lt D_i(X)Di‚Äã(X‚Ä≤)<Di‚Äã(X) for all i‚ààNi\in\mathcal Ni‚ààN.
  • Oblivious, does not depend on sensitive attribute or protected sub-groups.
  • Robust to outlier.
  • Scale invariant: a multiplicative scaling of all distances does not affect the set of PROP solution.
  • Approximately PROP can be efficiently computed.
  • Can be efficiently checked: no need to compute entire pairwise distance matrix.

However, PROP is incompatible with kkk-center, kkk-means, kkk-median in the worst case.

üìñDefinition 2. X‚äÜMX\subseteq\mathcal MX‚äÜM with ‚à£X‚à£=k|X|=k‚à£X‚à£=k is œÅ\rhoœÅ-approximate proportional (abbr. œÅ\rhoœÅ-proportional) if ‚àÄS‚äÜN\forall S\subseteq\mathcal N‚àÄS‚äÜN with ‚à£S‚à£>‚åànk‚åâ|S|\gt\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚à£S‚à£>‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ and ‚àÄy‚ààM\forall y\in\mathcal M‚àÄy‚ààM, there exists i‚ààSi\in Si‚ààS with œÅ‚ãÖd(i,y)‚â•Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)œÅ‚ãÖd(i,y)‚â•Di‚Äã(X).

Results and Outline

Existence of PROP and its approximation

PROP clustering solution doesn‚Äôt always exist.

  • Better than 222-PROP solution doesn‚Äôt always exist.

A greedy algorithm yields (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2‚Äã)-PROP solution in the worst case.

PROP as constraint

To optimize kkk-median objective subject to PROP constraint.

Use the rounding to find an O(1)O(1)O(1)-PROP solution to the kkk-median.

PROP and Randomness

PROP is approximately preserved if we take a random sample of the data points of size O~(k3)\tilde{O}(k^3)O~(k3).

For constant kkk, we can check if a given clustering s proportional as well as compute approximately PROP solutions in near linear time, comparable to the time for classic kkk-means heuristic.

Existence and Computation of PROP Solutions

ü§îClaim 1. For all œÅ<2\rho\lt2œÅ<2, a œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP solution is not guaranteed to exist.

Consider instance N={ai},M={xi}\mathcal N=\{a_i\},\mathcal M=\{x_i\}N={ai‚Äã},M={xi‚Äã} with ‚à£N‚à£=‚à£M‚à£=6,k=3|\mathcal N|=|\mathcal M|=6,k=3‚à£N‚à£=‚à£M‚à£=6,k=3 with distance:

x1x2x3x4x5x6
a1412‚àû‚àû‚àû
a2241‚àû‚àû‚àû
a3124‚àû‚àû‚àû
a4‚àû‚àû‚àû412
a5‚àû‚àû‚àû241
a6‚àû‚àû‚àû124

It‚Äôs easy to check that any solution can not be better than 222-PROP.

ü§îClaim 2. In case where N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M, for all œÅ<1.5\rho\lt1.5œÅ<1.5, a œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP solution is not guaranteed to exist.

A counterexample in the paper.

Computing 2.414-PROP Clustering

Let B(x,Œ¥)={i‚ààN:d(i,x)‚â§Œ¥}B(x,\delta)=\{i\in\mathcal N:d(i,x)\le\delta\}B(x,Œ¥)={i‚ààN:d(i,x)‚â§Œ¥} (The ball of distance Œ¥\deltaŒ¥ about center xxx).

Pseudo Code - Greedy Capture

  1. Œ¥‚Üê0,X‚Üê‚àÖ,N‚ÜêN\delta\gets0,X\gets\empty,N\gets\mathcal NŒ¥‚Üê0,X‚Üê‚àÖ,N‚ÜêN
  2. while N‚â†‚àÖN\neq\emptyNÓÄ†=‚àÖ, do
    • Smoothly increase Œ¥\deltaŒ¥
    • while ‚àÉx‚ààX\exist x\in X‚àÉx‚ààX s.t. ‚à£B(x,Œ¥)‚à©N‚à£‚â•1|B(x,\delta)\cap N|\ge1‚à£B(x,Œ¥)‚à©N‚à£‚â•1 do
      • N‚ÜêN‚ï≤B(x,Œ¥)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)N‚ÜêN‚ï≤B(x,Œ¥).
    • while ‚àÉx‚àà(M‚ï≤X)\exist x\in(\mathcal M\diagdown X)‚àÉx‚àà(M‚ï≤X) s.t. ‚à£B(x,Œ¥)‚à™N‚à£‚â•‚åànk‚åâ|B(x,\delta)\cup N|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚à£B(x,Œ¥)‚à™N‚à£‚â•‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ do
      • X‚ÜêX‚à™{x}X\gets X\cup\{x\}X‚ÜêX‚à™{x}
      • N‚ÜêN‚ï≤B(x,Œ¥)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta)N‚ÜêN‚ï≤B(x,Œ¥)
  3. return XXX

Greedy Capture runs in O~(mn)\tilde O(mn)O~(mn) time.

The algorithm continuously grows. When the ball around a center has captured ‚åànk‚åâ\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ points, we open that center and disregards all of the captured points.

Difference between kkk-means and kkk-median: Balls grow around data points in kkk-median instead of centers.

üéØTheorem 1. Greedy Capture algorithm yields a (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2‚Äã)-PROP clustering, and there exists an instance for which this bound is tight.

  1. XXX uses at most kkk centers, because it only opens a center when ‚åànk‚åâ\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ unmatched points are absorbed by the sphere. This can only happen at most kkk times.
  2. Suppose for contradiction that XXX is not (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2‚Äã)-PROP. ‚Ä¶

The example where Greedy Capture yields exactly this bound: N={a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,a6},M={x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,x4},k=3\mathcal N=\{a_1,\cdots,a_6\},\mathcal M=\{x_1,\cdots,x_4\},k=3N={a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,a6‚Äã},M={x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,x4‚Äã},k=3.

x1x2x3x4
a111+‚àö2‚àû‚àû
a2‚àö2-11-Œµ‚àû‚àû
a31+‚àö21-Œµ‚àû‚àû
a4‚àû‚àû11+‚àö2
a5‚àû‚àû‚àö2-11-Œµ
a6‚àû‚àû1+‚àö21-Œµ
  • Greedy Capture will open x2x_2x2‚Äã and x4x_4x4‚Äã. The coalition {a1,a2}\{a_1,a_2\}{a1‚Äã,a2‚Äã} can each reduce their distance by factor 1+21+\sqrt21+2‚Äã and œµ‚Üí0\epsilon\to0œµ‚Üí0 by deviating to x1x_1x1‚Äã.

I strongly suspect that the PROP fairness notion in clustering is thought after the algorithm.ü§ê

‚ùìOpen Problem: Can we fill the gap between 1+21+\sqrt 21+2‚Äã and 222 by inventing new algorithm? Or can we invent a new algorithm that has a better bound than 1+21+\sqrt21+2‚Äã?

Local Capture Heuristic

Local Capture heuristic produces more proportional clustering.

It takes a target value of œÅ\rhoœÅ as a parameter, and proceeds by iteratively finding a center that violates œÅ\rhoœÅ-fairness and swapping it for the center in the current solution that is least demanded.

Pseudo Code - LCH

Input: œÅ\rhoœÅ

  1. Initialize XXX as a random subset of kkk centers from M\mathcal MM.
  2. repeat until no changes occur:
    1. for y‚ààMy\in\mathcal My‚ààM do
      • Sy‚Üê{i‚ààN:œÅ‚ãÖdiy<Di(X)}S_y\gets\{i\in N:\rho\cdot d_{iy}\lt D_i(X)\}Sy‚Äã‚Üê{i‚ààN:œÅ‚ãÖdiy‚Äã<Di‚Äã(X)}
      • if ‚à£Sy‚à£‚â•‚åànk‚åâ|S_y|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚à£Sy‚Äã‚à£‚â•‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ then
        • x‚àó‚Üêarg‚Å°min‚Å°x‚ààX‚à£{i‚ààN:dix=Di(X)}‚à£x^*\gets\arg\min_{x\in X}|\{i\in N:d_{ix}=D_i(X)\}|x‚àó‚Üêargminx‚ààX‚Äã‚à£{i‚ààN:dix‚Äã=Di‚Äã(X)}‚à£
        • X‚Üê(X‚ï≤{x‚àó})‚à™{y}X\gets(X\diagdown\{x^*\})\cup\{y\}X‚Üê(X‚ï≤{x‚àó})‚à™{y}
  3. return XXX

LCH runs in O~(mn2)\tilde O(mn^2)O~(mn2) time. No guarantee of convergence! aka for a given œÅ\rhoœÅ, there may not exist a œÅ\rhoœÅ-proportional solution.

If LCH terminate, it must return a œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP solution.

PROP as a Constraint

Problem with LCH and Greedy Capture: They may find a PROP clustering with poor global objective, even when exact PROP clustering with good global objectives exist.

A bad example: k=2k=2k=2, two easily defined clusters containing 40%,60%40\%,60\%40%,60% of the data points respectively. It is possible Greedy Capture only open one point in the larger cluster. It is PROP, but not optimized w.r.t. main object.

So we need to solve this problem by optimizing the kkk-median objective subject to PROP as a constraint.

Consider kkk-median and kkk-means.

üéØTheorem 2. There is a œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective ccc. In polynomial time in mmm and nnn, we can compute a O(œÅ)O(\rho)O(œÅ)-PROP clustering with kkk-median objective at most 8c8c8c.

We can compute a constant approximate PROP with kkk-median objective at most eight times the minimum kkk-median objective PROP clustering.

Linear Programming

The standard linear programming relaxation of the kkk-median minimization problem. Then add a constraint to encode PROP.

Minimize¬†‚àëi‚ààN‚àëj‚ààMd(i,j)zij¬†¬†(1)Subject¬†to¬†‚àëj‚ààMzij=1‚àÄi‚ààN¬†¬†(2)zij‚â§yj‚àÄj‚ààM,‚àÄi‚ààN¬†¬†(3)‚àëj‚ààMyj‚â§k¬†¬†(4)‚àëj‚Ä≤‚ààB(j,Œ≥Rj)yj‚Ä≤‚â•1‚àÄj‚ààM¬†¬†(5)zij,yj‚àà[0,1]‚àÄj‚ààM,‚àÄi‚ààN¬†¬†(6)\text{Minimize }\sum_{i\in\mathcal N}\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}d(i,j)z_{ij}\ \ (1)\\\text{Subject to }\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}z_{ij}=1\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (2)\\z_{ij}\le y_j\forall j\in\mathcal M,\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (3)\\\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}y_j\le k\ \ (4)\\\sum_{j'\in B(j,\gamma R_j)}y_{j'}\ge1\forall j\in\mathcal M\ \ (5)\\z_{ij},y_j\in[0,1]\forall j\in\mathcal M,\forall i\in\mathcal N\ \ (6)Minimize¬†i‚ààN‚àë‚Äãj‚ààM‚àë‚Äãd(i,j)zij‚Äã¬†¬†(1)Subject¬†to¬†j‚ààM‚àë‚Äãzij‚Äã=1‚àÄi‚ààN¬†¬†(2)zij‚Äã‚â§yj‚Äã‚àÄj‚ààM,‚àÄi‚ààN¬†¬†(3)j‚ààM‚àë‚Äãyj‚Äã‚â§k¬†¬†(4)j‚Ä≤‚ààB(j,Œ≥Rj‚Äã)‚àë‚Äãyj‚Ä≤‚Äã‚â•1‚àÄj‚ààM¬†¬†(5)zij‚Äã,yj‚Äã‚àà[0,1]‚àÄj‚ààM,‚àÄi‚ààN¬†¬†(6)

B(j,Œ≥R)B(j,\gamma R)B(j,Œ≥R) is the ball with center jjj with radius Œ≥R\gamma RŒ≥R.

zijz_{ij}zij‚Äã is the indicator variable equal to 111 if i‚ààNi\in\mathcal Ni‚ààN is matched to j‚ààMj\in\mathcal Mj‚ààM.

yjy_jyj‚Äã is the indicator variable equal to 111 if j‚ààXj\in Xj‚ààX, i.e., if we want to use the center jjj in the clustering.

  • Objective (1) is the kkk-median objective.
  • Constraint (2) requires that every point must be matched.
  • Constraint (3) ensures that every points must be matched to the only center.
  • Constraint (4) allows at most kkk centers to be opened.
  • Constraint (6) relax the indicator to be real value between 000 and 111.

The elaboration of constraint (5): it approximately encodes PROP. Let RjR_jRj‚Äã be the minimum value s.t. ‚à£B(j,Rj)‚à£‚â•‚åànk‚åâ|B(j,R_j)|\ge\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚à£B(j,Rj‚Äã)‚à£‚â•‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ. aka RjR_jRj‚Äã is the distance of the ‚åànk‚åâ\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ farthest point in N\mathcal NN from jjj.

ü§îLemma 1. Let XXX be a clustering, Œ≥‚â•1\gamma\ge1Œ≥‚â•1. If ‚àÄj‚ààM\forall j\in \mathcal M‚àÄj‚ààM there exists some x‚ààXx\in Xx‚ààX s.t. d(j,x)‚â§Œ≥Rjd(j,x)\le\gamma R_jd(j,x)‚â§Œ≥Rj‚Äã, then XXX is (1+Œ≥)(1+\gamma)(1+Œ≥)-PROP. If XXX is Œ≥\gammaŒ≥-PROP, then ‚àÄj‚ààM\forall j\in \mathcal M‚àÄj‚ààM there exists some x‚ààXx\in Xx‚ààX s.t. d(j,x)‚â§(1+Œ≥)Rjd(j,x)\le(1+\gamma)R_jd(j,x)‚â§(1+Œ≥)Rj‚Äã.

Proof by contradiction and triangle inequality.

So œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP clustering XXX with kkk-median objective ccc. In constraint (5) Œ≥=œÅ+1\gamma=\rho+1Œ≥=œÅ+1. Lemma 1 guarantees that XXX is feasible for LP.

So the fractional solution has kkk-median objective is at most ccc. Then round the resulting fractional solution. A variation of rounding algorithm preserves constraint (5).

ü§îLemma 2. Let {yj},{zij}\{y_j\},\{z_{ij}\}{yj‚Äã},{zij‚Äã} be a fractional solution to the linear program in LP. There is an integer solution {y^j},{z^ij}\{\hat y_j\},\{\hat z_{ij}\}{y^‚Äãj‚Äã},{z^ij‚Äã} that is 888-approximation to the objective, and that opens kkk centers. Furthermore, for all j‚ààMj\in\mathcal Mj‚ààM, ‚àëj‚Ä≤‚ààB(j,27Œ≥Rj)y^j‚Ä≤‚â•1\sum_{j'\in B(j,27\gamma R_j)}\hat y_{j'}\ge1‚àëj‚Ä≤‚ààB(j,27Œ≥Rj‚Äã)‚Äãy^‚Äãj‚Ä≤‚Äã‚â•1.

Lemma 1 + 2 implies result of the rounding (27(1+œÅ)+1)(27(1+\rho)+1)(27(1+œÅ)+1)-PROP, by setting Œ≥=1+œÅ\gamma=1+\rhoŒ≥=1+œÅ. Since kkk-median objective of the fractional solution is at most ccc, kkk-median objective of the rounded solution is at most 8c8c8c by proof. The factor 272727 can be improved to 131313 in the special case where N=M\mathcal N=\mathcal MN=M.

Proof of Lemma 2

Argument is to show that with constraint (5), after rounding, the results is still approximately satisfied.

Given a fractional solution to the linear program as {yj},{zij}\{y_j\},\{z_{ij}\}{yj‚Äã},{zij‚Äã}, let CÀâi=‚àëj‚ààMd(i,j)zij\bar C_i=\sum_{j\in\mathcal M}d(i,j)z_{ij}CÀâi‚Äã=‚àëj‚ààM‚Äãd(i,j)zij‚Äã aka contribution of point iii to the kkk-median objective in the fractional optimum.

  • Step 1: Consolidate all demands tit_iti‚Äã (for all points it is set to 111) to obtain {ti‚Ä≤}\{t_i'\}{ti‚Ä≤‚Äã} s.t. ‚àÄi,j‚ààM\forall i,j\in\mathcal M‚àÄi,j‚ààM with ti‚Ä≤,tj‚Ä≤>0t_i',t_j'\gt0ti‚Ä≤‚Äã,tj‚Ä≤‚Äã>0, they must be sufficiently far away s.t. cij>4max‚Å°(CÀâi,CÀâj)c_{ij}\gt4\max(\bar C_i,\bar C_j)cij‚Äã>4max(CÀâi‚Äã,CÀâj‚Äã). Let M‚Ä≤\mathcal M'M‚Ä≤ be the set of centers with positive demand after this step, i.e., M‚Ä≤={j‚ààM:tj‚Ä≤>0}\mathcal M'=\{j\in\mathcal M:t_j'\gt0\}M‚Ä≤={j‚ààM:tj‚Ä≤‚Äã>0}.
  • Step 2a: Consolidate open centers by moving each center not in M‚Ä≤\mathcal M'M‚Ä≤ to the nearest center in M‚Ä≤\mathcal M'M‚Ä≤.
  • Step 2b: ‚Ä¶
  • ‚Ä¶

Very complex.

Sampling for Linear-Time Implementations and Auditing

PROP under uniform random sampling.

Draw ‚à£N‚à£|N|‚à£N‚à£ individuals independent and identically distributed from the uniform distribution on N\mathcal NN.

This paper shows that PROP is well preserved under random sampling.

PROP Under Random Sampling

For any X‚äÜMX\subseteq\mathcal MX‚äÜM of size kkk and center y‚ààMy\in\mathcal My‚ààM, define R(N,X,y)={i‚ààN:Di(X)>œÅ‚ãÖd(i,y)}R(\mathcal N,X,y)=\{i\in\mathcal N:D_i(X)\gt\rho\cdot d(i,y)\}R(N,X,y)={i‚ààN:Di‚Äã(X)>œÅ‚ãÖd(i,y)}. Note that XXX is not œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP w.r.t. N\mathcal NN iff there is some y‚ààMy\in\mathcal My‚ààM s.t. ‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚â•1k\frac{|R(\mathcal N,X,y)|}{|\mathcal N|}\ge\frac{1}{k}‚à£N‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚Äã‚â•k1‚Äã.

A random sample approximately preserves this fraction for all solution XXX and deviating centers yyy.

Proof sketch: we take a union bound over all possible solutions and deviations, and there are only k‚ãÖCmkk\cdot C_m^kk‚ãÖCmk‚Äã such combinations.

ü§îüéØTheorem 3. Given N,M\mathcal N,\mathcal MN,M and parameter œÅ‚â•1\rho\ge1œÅ‚â•1, fix parameters œµ,Œ¥‚àà[0,1]\epsilon,\delta\in[0,1]œµ,Œ¥‚àà[0,1]. Let N‚äÜNN\subseteq\mathcal NN‚äÜN of size Œ©(k3œµ2log‚Å°mŒ¥)\Omega(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}\log\frac{m}{\delta})Œ©(œµ2k3‚ÄãlogŒ¥m‚Äã) be chosen uniformly at random. Then, with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1-\delta1‚àíŒ¥, the following holds for all (X,y)(X,y)(X,y):

‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚àí‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚à£‚â§œµk\left\vert\frac{\vert R(N,X,y)\vert}{\vert N\vert}-\frac{\vert R(\mathcal N,X,y)\vert}{\vert\mathcal N\vert}\right\vert\le\frac{\epsilon}{k}‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚Äã‚à£N‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚Äã‚àí‚à£N‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚Äã‚â§kœµ‚Äã

Â∑≤ÁªèÂØπ 1‚àíŒ¥1-\delta1‚àíŒ¥ÔºåO/Œ©(1œµlog‚Å°1Œ¥)O/\Omega(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\delta})O/Œ©(œµ1‚ÄãlogŒ¥1‚Äã), Chernoff, Hoeffding ËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑ‰∏úË•ø PTSD ‰∫ÜË∞¢Ë∞¢

NNN is a random sample of N\mathcal NN. Hoeffding‚Äôs inequality implies that for any fixed (X,y)(X,y)(X,y), a sample of size ‚à£N‚à£=O(1œµ^2log‚Å°1Œ¥^)|N|=O(\frac{1}{\hat\epsilon^2}\log\frac{1}{\hat\delta})‚à£N‚à£=O(œµ^21‚ÄãlogŒ¥^1‚Äã) is sufficient to achieve

‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚àí‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚à£‚â§œµ^\left\vert\frac{\vert R(N,X,y)\vert}{\vert N\vert}-\frac{\vert R(\mathcal N,X,y)\vert}{\vert\mathcal N\vert}\right\vert\le\hat\epsilon‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚Äã‚à£N‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚Äã‚àí‚à£N‚à£‚à£R(N,X,y)‚à£‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚à£‚Äã‚â§œµ^

with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥^1-\hat\delta1‚àíŒ¥^. Note that there are q=m‚ãÖCmkq=m\cdot C_m^kq=m‚ãÖCmk‚Äã possible choice of (X,y)(X,y)(X,y) over which we take the union bound. Setting Œ¥=Œ¥^q,œµ=œµ^k\delta=\frac{\hat\delta}{q},\epsilon=\frac{\hat\epsilon}{k}Œ¥=qŒ¥^‚Äã,œµ=kœµ^‚Äã is sufficient for the union bound to yield the theorem.

We say solution XXX is œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP to (1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ)-deviations if for all y‚ààMy\in\mathcal My‚ààM and for all S‚äÜNS\subseteq\mathcal NS‚äÜN where ‚à£S‚à£‚â•(1+œµ)nk|S|\ge(1+\epsilon)\frac{n}{k}‚à£S‚à£‚â•(1+œµ)kn‚Äã, there exists some i‚ààSi\in Si‚ààS s.t. œÅ‚ãÖd(i,y)‚â•Di(X)\rho\cdot d(i,y)\ge D_i(X)œÅ‚ãÖd(i,y)‚â•Di‚Äã(X). Note that if XXX is œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP to 111-deviation, it is simply œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP.

ü§îCorollary 1. Let N‚äÇNN\subset\mathcal NN‚äÇN be a uniform random sample of size ‚à£N‚à£=Œ©(k3œµ2ln‚Å°mŒ¥)|N|=\Omega(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}\ln\frac{m}{\delta})‚à£N‚à£=Œ©(œµ2k3‚ÄãlnŒ¥m‚Äã). Suppose X‚äÜMX\subseteq MX‚äÜM with ‚à£X‚à£=k|X|=k‚à£X‚à£=k is œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP w.r.t. NNN. Then with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1-\delta1‚àíŒ¥, XXX is œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP to (1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ)-deviations w.r.t. N\mathcal NN.

Linear Time Implementation

We can approximately implement Greedy Capture in nearly linear time, comparable to the running time of the standard kkk-means heuristic.

ü§îCorollary 2. Greedy Capture, when run on M\mathcal MM and a random sample N‚äÜNN\subseteq\mathcal NN‚äÜN of size ‚à£N‚à£=Œò~(k3œµ2)|N|=\tilde\Theta(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2})‚à£N‚à£=Œò~(œµ2k3‚Äã), provides a solution that is (1+2)(1+\sqrt 2)(1+2‚Äã)-PROP to (1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ)-deviation with high probability in O~(k3œµ2m)\tilde O(\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2}m)O~(œµ2k3‚Äãm) time.

There are similar speedup for Local Capture algorithm.

Efficient Auditing

Audit Problem: To answer whether a solution produced happens to be proportional.

Given N,M\mathcal N,\mathcal MN,M, X‚äÇNX\subset \mathcal NX‚äÇN with ‚à£X‚à£<k|X|\lt k‚à£X‚à£<k, find the minimum value of œÅ\rhoœÅ s.t. XXX is œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP.

Trivial idea: One can solve the audit problem exactly in O((k+m)n)O((k+m)n)O((k+m)n) time by computing for each y‚ààMy\in\mathcal My‚ààM, the quantity œÅy\rho_yœÅy‚Äã, the ‚åànk‚åâ\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil‚åàkn‚Äã‚åâ largest value of Di(X)d(i,y)\frac{D_i(X)}{d(i,y)}d(i,y)Di‚Äã(X)‚Äã. Then find the yyy that maximizes œÅy\rho_yœÅy‚Äã. Again, this takes quadratic time, which can be worse than the time taken to find the clustering itself.

(œµ,Œ¥)(\epsilon,\delta)(œµ,Œ¥)-Audit Problem: Find the minimum value of œÅ\rhoœÅ s.t. XXX is œÅ\rhoœÅ-PROP to (1+œµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+œµ)-deviations with probability at least 1‚àíŒ¥1-\delta1‚àíŒ¥. This problem can be efficiently solved by using a random sample N‚äÜNN\subseteq\mathcal NN‚äÜN of points to conduct the audit.

ü§îCorollary 3. The (œµ,Œ¥)(\epsilon,\delta)(œµ,Œ¥)-Audit Problem can be solved in O~((k+m)k3œµ2)\tilde O((k+m)\frac{k^3}{\epsilon^2})O~((k+m)œµ2k3‚Äã) time.

Implementation and Empirical Results

Highly depends on which dataset.

Conclusion and Open Problems

The exact PROP may not exist.

Efficient algorithms for computing approximate PROP solutions.

Constrained optimization and sampling for further applications.

Finally, PROP on real data: data dependent trade-off between PROP and kkk-means objective.

Open Problems

‚ùìCan we close the approximate factor gap between 222 and 1+21+\sqrt21+2‚Äã?

‚ùìIs there a more efficient and easily explainable algorithm for optimizing total cost subject to PROP?

‚ùìIs there any other fair solution concepts for clustering?

‚ùìCan the idea of PROP as a group fairness concept be adapted for supervised learning tasks like classification and regression?
entry.summary: Read the paper Proportionally Fair Clustering by Chen et al.

entry.title: Fair AI/ML 1 Core-Stability Federated Learning
entry.content:
I will begin a new project work 24 Fall: FAIRNESS IN AI/ML THROUGH THE LENS OF SOCIAL CHOICE

The basic outline is following Tutorial: Fairness in AI/ML via Social Choice by Evi Micha & Nisarg Shah in EC 2024.

The first paper I have read in last semester, Fairness in Federated Learning via Core-Stability, which was one of the possible topics.

Brief notes is here.

I will try to understand some mathematical proof in this semester.

Core-Stability

Revisit the definition of Core-Stability: A predictor Œ∏‚ààP\theta\in PŒ∏‚ààP is called core stable if there exist no other Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP\theta'\in PŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP and no subset SSS of agents, s.t. ‚à£S‚à£nui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•ui(Œ∏)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)n‚à£S‚à£‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•ui‚Äã(Œ∏) for all i‚ààSi\in Si‚ààS, with at least one strict inequality.

‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏èWhat is WRONG with the claim

Setting S=[n]S=[n]S=[n] in definition, there is no predictor Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP\theta'\in PŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP where ‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏)>n\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt n‚àëi‚àà[n]‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã>n.

According to the definition, when we plug in S=[n]S=[n]S=[n], there exist no Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP\theta'\in PŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP s.t.

ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•ui(Œ∏)‚àÄi‚ààS‚áîui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏)‚â•1‚àÄi‚ààSu_i(\theta')\ge u_i(\theta)\forall i\in S\\\Lrarr\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\ge 1\forall i\in Sui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•ui‚Äã(Œ∏)‚àÄi‚ààS‚áîui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚â•1‚àÄi‚ààS

with at least one strict inequality.

The problem is, can we directly sum it up, then we have ‚àëiui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏)>n\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}\gt n‚àëi‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã>n???

There is a counterexample:

  • n=2n=2n=2, Œ∏\thetaŒ∏ is core-stable, we only have two feasible predictors Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤:Œ∏‚Ä≤‚â†Œ∏\theta,\theta':\theta'\neq\thetaŒ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤:Œ∏‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=Œ∏, œµ‚Üí0+\epsilon\to0^+œµ‚Üí0+.

    agent 111agent 222
    Œ∏\thetaŒ∏111111
    Œ∏‚Ä≤\theta'Œ∏‚Ä≤2‚àíœµ2-\epsilon2‚àíœµ1‚àíœµ1-\epsilon1‚àíœµ

  • Verifying the core-stability of Œ∏\thetaŒ∏:

    • For S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}, we have ‚à£S‚à£nui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=12u1(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=1‚àíœµ2<1=u1(Œ∏)\frac{|S|}{n}u_i(\theta')=\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta')=1-\frac{\epsilon}{2}\lt1=u_1(\theta)n‚à£S‚à£‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=21‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=1‚àí2œµ‚Äã<1=u1‚Äã(Œ∏). Which satisfy the condition.
    • For S={2}S=\{2\}S={2}, we have 12u2(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=1‚àíœµ2<1=u2(Œ∏)\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta')=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt1=u_2(\theta)21‚Äãu2‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=21‚àíœµ‚Äã<1=u2‚Äã(Œ∏). Which satisfy the condition.
    • For S={1,2}S=\{1,2\}S={1,2}, we have u1(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=2‚àíœµ>1=u1(Œ∏)u_1(\theta')=2-\epsilon\gt1=u_1(\theta)u1‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=2‚àíœµ>1=u1‚Äã(Œ∏) and u2(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=1‚àíœµ<1=u2(Œ∏)u_2(\theta')=1-\epsilon\lt1=u_2(\theta)u2‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)=1‚àíœµ<1=u2‚Äã(Œ∏). Which also satisfy the condition that some scaled utility is less than the original utility.

    But ‚àëiui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏)=u1(Œ∏‚Ä≤)u1(Œ∏)+u2(Œ∏‚Ä≤)u2(Œ∏)=3‚àí2œµ>2\sum_i\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}=\frac{u_1(\theta')}{u_1(\theta)}+\frac{u_2(\theta')}{u_2(\theta)}=3-2\epsilon\gt2‚àëi‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã=u1‚Äã(Œ∏)u1‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã+u2‚Äã(Œ∏)u2‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã=3‚àí2œµ>2!

Scaled factor ‚à£S‚à£/n|S|/n‚à£S‚à£/n suggests some kind of proportionality here. Basically core-stability means there is no big benefit for agent to form a coalition.

Core means ‚Äúno deviating subgroup‚Äù

Core stability is very strong, only exists in special cases.

Advantage

More fair than FedAvg. MMM is a very large integer.

Agent 1Agent 2Agent 3
Œ∏1\theta_1Œ∏1‚ÄãaaaaaaM‚ãÖaM\cdot aM‚ãÖa
Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚Äã10a10a10a10a10a10a0.9M‚ãÖa0.9M\cdot a0.9M‚ãÖa

In FedAvg, Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚Äã is preferred, but not fair to Agent 1 and 2. (They have incentive to collide.)

Robustness to poor local data quality of agents.

‚ùóScaling the utility of any single agents does not change the core-stable allocation.

‚ùóSome Ideas around Sum-of-ratio Property

Is there scenario s.t. none of predictors is core-stable?

Yes. The example

agent 111agent 222
Œ∏\thetaŒ∏1112+œµ2+\epsilon2+œµ
Œ∏‚Ä≤\theta'Œ∏‚Ä≤2+œµ2+\epsilon2+œµ111

shows that none of Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤\theta,\theta'Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤ is core-stable.

Some New Definitions

Ideas from Iannis. I was amazed by his ability to invent some new notions üòÆ

üìñDefinition of pessimistic price of core-stability:

PoCSpessimistic=max‚Å°Œ∏¬†is¬†core-stablemax‚Å°Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏)PoCS_{pessimistic}=\max_{\theta\text{ is core-stable}}\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}PoCSpessimistic‚Äã=Œ∏¬†is¬†core-stablemax‚ÄãŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààPmax‚Äãi‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã

üìñDefinition of optimistic price of core-stability:

PoCSoptimistic=min‚Å°Œ∏¬†is¬†core-stablemax‚Å°Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏)PoCS_{optimistic}=\min_{\theta\text{ is core-stable}}\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta)}PoCSoptimistic‚Äã=Œ∏¬†is¬†core-stablemin‚ÄãŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààPmax‚Äãi‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã

Conjecture about Price of Core-Stability (Has been disproved)

If the set of core-stable predictors is non-empty, does one predictor in the set be the optimistic price of core-stability?

We want to proof/disproof this conjectures.

Let‚Äôs consider the scenario with two agents.

agents\predictorsŒ∏\thetaŒ∏‚Ä¶Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤\theta''Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä¶
11‚Ä¶?‚Ä¶
21‚Ä¶?‚Ä¶

Assume that Œ∏\thetaŒ∏ is core-stable. The question is, does there exist predictor Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤\theta''Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ that minimizing max‚Å°Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)\max_{\theta'\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta'')}maxŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP‚Äã‚àëi‚àà[n]‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã and not core-stable? If the answer is true, then we disproof the conjecture.

Disprove it

Consider the scenario with 2 agents and 3 feasible predictors:

agents\predictorsŒ∏1\theta_1Œ∏1‚ÄãŒ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚ÄãŒ∏3\theta_3Œ∏3‚Äã
11111‚àíœµ1-\epsilon1‚àíœµ222
21112221‚àíœµ1-\epsilon1‚àíœµ

By symmetry, Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚Äã and Œ∏3\theta_3Œ∏3‚Äã are equivalent.

Check whether Œ∏1\theta_1Œ∏1‚Äã is core-stable

  • Consider S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}:

    12u1(Œ∏2)=1‚àíœµ2<1=u1(Œ∏1)=112u1(Œ∏3)=22=1‚â§1=u1(Œ∏1)=1\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_2)=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt 1=u_1(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=\frac{2}{2}=1\le 1=u_1(\theta_1)=121‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)=21‚àíœµ‚Äã<1=u1‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=121‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)=22‚Äã=1‚â§1=u1‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=1

  • Consider S={2}S=\{2\}S={2}:

    12u2(Œ∏3)=1‚àíœµ2<1=u2(Œ∏1)=112u2(Œ∏2)=22=1‚â§1=u2(Œ∏1)=1\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta_3)=\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\lt 1=u_2(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{1}{2}u_2(\theta_2)=\frac{2}{2}=1\le 1=u_2(\theta_1)=121‚Äãu2‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)=21‚àíœµ‚Äã<1=u2‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=121‚Äãu2‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)=22‚Äã=1‚â§1=u2‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=1

  • Consider S={1,2}S=\{1,2\}S={1,2}:

    22u1(Œ∏2)=1‚àíœµ<u1(Œ∏1)=1,22u2(Œ∏2)=2>u2(Œ∏1)=122u1(Œ∏3)=2>u1(Œ∏1)=1,22u1(Œ∏3)=1‚àíœµ<u1(Œ∏1)=1\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon\lt u_1(\theta_1)=1,\frac{2}{2}u_2(\theta_2)=2\gt u_2(\theta_1)=1\\\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=2\gt u_1(\theta_1)=1,\frac{2}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=1-\epsilon\lt u_1(\theta_1)=122‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)=1‚àíœµ<u1‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=1,22‚Äãu2‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)=2>u2‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=122‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)=2>u1‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=1,22‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)=1‚àíœµ<u1‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=1

There is no subset satisfying all scaled value is greater or equal to original value. Thus, Œ∏1\theta_1Œ∏1‚Äã is core-stable.

Check whether Œ∏2,Œ∏3\theta_2,\theta_3Œ∏2‚Äã,Œ∏3‚Äã are core-stable

It suffices to check only Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚Äã.

  • Consider S={1}S=\{1\}S={1}:

    12u1(Œ∏1)=12<u1(Œ∏2)=1‚àíœµ12u1(Œ∏3)=1>u1(Œ∏2)=1‚àíœµ\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_1)=\frac{1}{2}\lt u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon\\\frac{1}{2}u_1(\theta_3)=1\gt u_1(\theta_2)=1-\epsilon21‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)=21‚Äã<u1‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)=1‚àíœµ21‚Äãu1‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)=1>u1‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)=1‚àíœµ

    Here scaled utility of Œ∏3\theta_3Œ∏3‚Äã is strictly better than that of Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚Äã.

Thus Œ∏2,Œ∏3\theta_2,\theta_3Œ∏2‚Äã,Œ∏3‚Äã are not core-stable.

Check the Sum of Ratio

For Œ∏1\theta_1Œ∏1‚Äã:

‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏2)ui(Œ∏1)=3‚àíœµ‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏3)ui(Œ∏1)=3‚àíœµ‚à¥max‚Å°Œ∏‚Ä≤‚â†Œ∏1‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏1)‚âà3\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_2)}{u_i(\theta_1)}=3-\epsilon\\\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_3)}{u_i(\theta_1)}=3-\epsilon\\\therefore\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_1}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_1)}\approx3i‚àà{1,2}‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)‚Äã=3‚àíœµi‚àà{1,2}‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)‚Äã=3‚àíœµ‚à¥Œ∏‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=Œ∏1‚Äãmax‚Äãi‚àà{1,2}‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚âà3

For Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚Äã:

‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏1)ui(Œ∏2)=12+11‚àíœµ‚âà32‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏3)ui(Œ∏2)=21‚àíœµ+1‚àíœµ2‚âà52‚à¥max‚Å°Œ∏‚Ä≤‚â†Œ∏2‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏2)‚âà52\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_1)}{u_i(\theta_2)}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{1-\epsilon}\approx\frac{3}{2}\\\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta_3)}{u_i(\theta_2)}=\frac{2}{1-\epsilon}+\frac{1-\epsilon}{2}\approx\frac{5}{2}\\\therefore\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_2}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_2)}\approx\frac{5}{2}i‚àà{1,2}‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏1‚Äã)‚Äã=21‚Äã+1‚àíœµ1‚Äã‚âà23‚Äãi‚àà{1,2}‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)‚Äã=1‚àíœµ2‚Äã+21‚àíœµ‚Äã‚âà25‚Äã‚à¥Œ∏‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=Œ∏2‚Äãmax‚Äãi‚àà{1,2}‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏2‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚âà25‚Äã

By symmetry, max‚Å°Œ∏‚Ä≤‚â†Œ∏3‚àëi‚àà{1,2}ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏3)‚âà52\max_{\theta'\neq\theta_3}\sum_{i\in\{1,2\}}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta_3)}\approx\frac{5}{2}maxŒ∏‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=Œ∏3‚Äã‚Äã‚àëi‚àà{1,2}‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏3‚Äã)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚âà25‚Äã.

The max of sum is not minimized by the only core-stable predictor.

Core-Stability in FL

CoreFed exists in Linear Regression and Logistic Regression (Classification)

Approximate core stable predictor exists in Deep Neural Network.

Existence

ü§îCore-Stability exist in FL if:

  1. Utility function is continuous.

  2. The conical combination of utility functions is convex.

    ‚àÄ‚ü®Œ±1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Œ±n‚ü©‚ààR‚â•0n\forall\langle\alpha_1,\cdots,\alpha_n\rangle\in\mathbb R_{\ge0}^n‚àÄ‚ü®Œ±1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Œ±n‚Äã‚ü©‚ààR‚â•0n‚Äã, the set C={Œ∏‚à£‚àëi‚àà[n]Œ±iui(Œ∏)}C=\{\theta|\sum_{i\in[n]}\alpha_iu_i(\theta)\}C={Œ∏‚à£‚àëi‚àà[n]‚ÄãŒ±i‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)} is convex.

ü§îImportant theorem: Kakutani‚Äôs Fixed Point Theorem: A set valued function œï:D‚Üí2D\phi:D\to2^Dœï:D‚Üí2D admits a fixed point, i.e. ‚àÉd‚ààD\exist d\in D‚àÉd‚ààD, s.t. d‚ààœï(d)d\in\phi(d)d‚ààœï(d), if

  1. DDD is non-empty, compact, and convex

Compact: The set is closed (It must contains all its boundary points), and bounded (It can be covered by a ‚Äúsphere‚Äù with certain radius)

Convex: A set is convex if, for any two points xxx and yyy in the set, the line segment connecting xxx and yyy also lies entirely within the set. Mathematically, for any x,y‚ààSx,y\in Sx,y‚ààS and any t‚àà[0,1]t \in [0, 1]t‚àà[0,1], the point: tx+(1‚àít)y‚ààStx+(1‚àít)y\in Stx+(1‚àít)y‚ààS.

  1. ‚àÄd‚ààD,œï(d)\forall d\in D,\phi(d)‚àÄd‚ààD,œï(d) is non-empty, compact, and convex.
  2. œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot)œï(‚ãÖ) has a closed graph. i.e., ‚àÄ\forall‚àÄ sequence (di)i‚ààN(d_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(di‚Äã)i‚ààN‚Äã converging to d‚àód^*d‚àó and (ei)i‚ààN(e_i)_{i\in\mathbb N}(ei‚Äã)i‚ààN‚Äã converging to e‚àóe^*e‚àó, s.t. di‚ààDd_i\in Ddi‚Äã‚ààD and ei‚ààœï(di)e_i\in\phi(d_i)ei‚Äã‚ààœï(di‚Äã), we have e‚àó‚ààœï(d‚àó)e^*\in\phi(d^*)e‚àó‚ààœï(d‚àó).

Define Core-Stable Feasible Predictors

‚àÄŒ∏‚ààP\forall\theta\in P‚àÄŒ∏‚ààP, œï(Œ∏)={arg‚Å°max‚Å°d‚ààP‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(d)ui(Œ∏)}\phi(\theta)=\{\arg\max_{d\in P}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(d)}{u_i(\theta)}\}œï(Œ∏)={argmaxd‚ààP‚Äã‚àëi‚àà[n]‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)ui‚Äã(d)‚Äã}.

Lemma 4.1: Let Œ∏‚ààP\theta\in PŒ∏‚ààP be s.t. Œ∏‚ààœï(Œ∏)\theta\in\phi(\theta)Œ∏‚ààœï(Œ∏) (It is a fixed point). Then Œ∏\thetaŒ∏ is a core-stable predictor.

Proof by contradiction.

By Takutani‚Äôs Theorem, it suffices to show that œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot)œï(‚ãÖ) has a closed graph, to ensure that it admits a fixed point.

Lemma 4.2: œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot)œï(‚ãÖ) has a closed graph.

Hard proof.

ü§îTheorem 1. In FL, where utilities are continuous and any conical combination of utilities is convex, a core-stable predictor exists.

‚ö†Ô∏èIf we change d‚ààPd\in Pd‚ààP to d‚ààB(Œ∏,r)d\in\mathcal B(\theta, r)d‚ààB(Œ∏,r), if the two condition still holds within a radius of rrr of every point. The conditions tend to be true in DNN of small rrr. Then the predictor is locally core-stable.

Computation of Core-Stable Predictor

There is efficient way to compute core-stable predictor.

It is optima of convex program:

maximize¬†L(Œ∏)=‚àëi‚àà[n]log‚Å°(ui(Œ∏))¬†or¬†‚àèi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏)subject¬†to¬†Œ∏‚ààP\text{maximize }\mathcal L(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(u_i(\theta))\text{ or }\prod_{i\in[n]}u_i(\theta)\\\text{subject to }\theta\in Pmaximize¬†L(Œ∏)=i‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãlog(ui‚Äã(Œ∏))¬†or¬†i‚àà[n]‚àè‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)subject¬†to¬†Œ∏‚ààP

The object reminds me of Nash Social Welfareüòé

Utility of each agent is concave, thus above program is convex. Thus this program is concave maximization subject to convex constraint.

ü§îTheorem 2. If uiu_iui‚Äã is concave for all iii, then any predictor Œ∏‚àó\theta^*Œ∏‚àó maximizes the convex program is core stable.

Proof by contradiction

‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui(Œ∏‚àó)‚â§n.\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta')}{u_i(\theta^*)}\le n.i‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚â§n.

If Œ∏‚àó\theta^*Œ∏‚àó is not core-stable, there must exist Œ∏‚Ä≤\theta'Œ∏‚Ä≤ and subset SSS, s.t.

ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•n‚à£S‚à£ui(Œ∏‚àó)u_i(\theta')\ge\frac{n}{|S|}u_i(\theta^*)ui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•‚à£S‚à£n‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚àó)

for all iii with at least one strict inequality.

Thus for any Œ∏‚â†Œ∏‚Ä≤\theta\neq\theta'Œ∏ÓÄ†=Œ∏‚Ä≤,

‚àëi‚àà[n]ui(Œ∏)ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚â•‚àëi‚ààSui(Œ∏)ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)>n/‚à£S‚à£‚ãÖ‚à£S‚à£=n,\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta')}\ge\sum_{i\in S}\frac{u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta')}\gt n/|S|\cdot|S|=n,i‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äã‚â•i‚ààS‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)ui‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äã>n/‚à£S‚à£‚ãÖ‚à£S‚à£=n,

admitting contradiction.

Œ∏‚àó\theta^*Œ∏‚àó must be Pareto Optimal.

CoreFed

Stochastic Gradient Descent.

nnn finite samples {(xi,yi)}i‚àà[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xi‚Äã,yi‚Äã)}i‚àà[n]‚Äã drawn from data distribution P\mathcal PP, which constitute empirical distribution P^n\hat{\mathcal P}_nP^n‚Äã. The gradient can be expressed as an conical combination of the gradients of each group:

‚àáŒ∏(Œ∏)=‚àëi‚àà[n]‚àáŒ∏ui(Œ∏)ui(Œ∏)=‚àëi‚àà[n]‚àí‚àáŒ∏E(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Ñì(fŒ∏(x),y)Mi‚àíE(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Ñì(fŒ∏(x),y)\nabla_\theta\mathcal(\theta)=\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{\nabla_\theta u_i(\theta)}{u_i(\theta)}=\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{-\nabla_\theta\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)}{M_i-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)}‚àáŒ∏‚Äã(Œ∏)=i‚àà[n]‚àë‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)‚àáŒ∏‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)‚Äã=i‚àà[n]‚àë‚ÄãMi‚Äã‚àíE(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Äã‚Äã‚Ñì(fŒ∏‚Äã(x),y)‚àí‚àáŒ∏‚ÄãE(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Äã‚Äã‚Ñì(fŒ∏‚Äã(x),y)‚Äã

For each group, reweight its gradients by (Mi‚àíE(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Ñì(fŒ∏(x),y))‚àí1(M_i-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y))^{-1}(Mi‚Äã‚àíE(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Äã‚Äã‚Ñì(fŒ∏‚Äã(x),y))‚àí1 and then sum up to get the final weight update. This is base protocol.

In CoreFed the model weights are directly averaged and aggregated at each iteration.

Pseudo Code of CoreFed

Input: Number of clients KKK, number of rounds TTT, epochs EEE, learning rate Œ∑\etaŒ∑.

Output: Model weights Œ∏‚ä§\theta^\topŒ∏‚ä§

  1. For t‚Üê0t\gets0t‚Üê0 to T‚àí1T-1T‚àí1 do

    • Server selects a subset of KKK devices StS_tSt‚Äã

    • Server sends weights Œ∏t\theta^tŒ∏t to all selected devices

    • Each select device s‚ààSts\in S_ts‚ààSt‚Äã updates Œ∏t\theta^tŒ∏t for EEE epochs of SGD with learning rate Œ∑\etaŒ∑ to obtain new weights Œ∏Àâst\bar\theta_s^tŒ∏Àâst‚Äã

    • Each select devices s‚ààSts\in S_ts‚ààSt‚Äã computes

      ŒîŒ∏st=Œ∏Àâst‚àíŒ∏t,Lst=1‚à£Ds‚à£‚àëi=1‚à£Ds‚à£‚Ñì(fŒ∏t(xs(i)),ys(i))\Delta\theta_s^t=\bar\theta_s^t-\theta^t,\\\mathcal L_s^t=\frac{1}{|\mathcal D_s|}\sum_{i=1}^{|\mathcal D_s|}\ell(f_{\theta^t}(x_s^{(i)}),y_s^{(i)})ŒîŒ∏st‚Äã=Œ∏Àâst‚Äã‚àíŒ∏t,Lst‚Äã=‚à£Ds‚Äã‚à£1‚Äãi=1‚àë‚à£Ds‚Äã‚à£‚Äã‚Ñì(fŒ∏t‚Äã(xs(i)‚Äã),ys(i)‚Äã)

      where Ds={(xs(i),ys(i)):i‚àà[‚à£Ds‚à£]}\mathcal D_s=\{(x_s^{(i)},y_s^{(i)}):i\in[|\mathcal D_s|]\}Ds‚Äã={(xs(i)‚Äã,ys(i)‚Äã):i‚àà[‚à£Ds‚Äã‚à£]} is the training dataset on device sss

    • Each selected device s‚ààSts\in S_ts‚ààSt‚Äã sends ŒîŒ∏s\Delta \theta_sŒîŒ∏s‚Äã and Ls\mathcal L_sLs‚Äã back to the server

    • Server updates Œ∏t+1\theta^{t+1}Œ∏t+1 following

      Œ∏t+1‚ÜêŒ∏t+1‚à£St‚à£‚àës‚ààStŒîŒ∏stMs‚àíLst.\theta^{t+1}\gets\theta^t+\frac{1}{|S_t|}\sum_{s\in S_t}\frac{\Delta\theta_s^t}{M_s-\mathcal L_s^t}.Œ∏t+1‚ÜêŒ∏t+‚à£St‚Äã‚à£1‚Äãs‚ààSt‚Äã‚àë‚ÄãMs‚Äã‚àíLst‚ÄãŒîŒ∏st‚Äã‚Äã.

end

Core-Stability in Linear Regression and Classification with Logistic Regression

Utility function is concave.

uiu_iui‚Äã is concave ‚áî‚Ñì\Lrarr \ell‚áî‚Ñì is convex

nnn finite samples {(xi,yi)}i‚àà[n]\{(x_i,y_i)\}_{i\in[n]}{(xi‚Äã,yi‚Äã)}i‚àà[n]‚Äã drawn from data distribution P\mathcal PP, which constitute empirical distribution P^n\hat{\mathcal P}_nP^n‚Äã.

Linear Regression

fŒ∏(x)=Œ∏‚ä§xf_\theta(x)=\theta^\top xfŒ∏‚Äã(x)=Œ∏‚ä§x.

Regression loss E(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Ñì(fŒ∏(x),y)=E(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)(Œ∏‚ä§x‚àíy)2\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}\ell(f_\theta(x),y)=\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim\hat{\mathcal P}_n^{(i)}}(\theta^\top x-y)^2E(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Äã‚Äã‚Ñì(fŒ∏‚Äã(x),y)=E(x,y)‚àºP^n(i)‚Äã‚Äã(Œ∏‚ä§x‚àíy)2 would be convex in Œ∏\thetaŒ∏

ü§îLemma: CoreFed determines a core-stable predictor in a federated learning setting training linear regression

Classification with Logistic Regression

Given a classifier Œ∏\thetaŒ∏ and a scalar c‚ààRc\in Rc‚ààR, and agents iii‚Äôs loss is ‚Ñìi(Œ∏,c)=‚à£‚à£Œ∏‚à£‚à£22+Œ±‚ãÖ‚àëi‚àà[n]log‚Å°(exp‚Å°(‚àíyi(Œ∏‚ä§xi+c))+1)\ell_i(\theta,c)=\frac{||\theta||_2}{2}+\alpha\cdot\sum_{i\in[n]}\log(\exp(-y_i(\theta^\top x_i+c))+1)‚Ñìi‚Äã(Œ∏,c)=2‚à£‚à£Œ∏‚à£‚à£2‚Äã‚Äã+Œ±‚ãÖ‚àëi‚àà[n]‚Äãlog(exp(‚àíyi‚Äã(Œ∏‚ä§xi‚Äã+c))+1). ‚Ñìi\ell_i‚Ñìi‚Äã is convex.

Thus, ui(Œ∏,c)=Mi‚àí‚Ñìi(Œ∏,c)u_i(\theta,c)=M_i-\ell_i(\theta,c)ui‚Äã(Œ∏,c)=Mi‚Äã‚àí‚Ñìi‚Äã(Œ∏,c) where Mi=arg‚Å°max‚Å°Œ∏‚ààP,c‚ààR(‚Ñìi(Œ∏,c))M_i=\arg\max_{\theta\in P,c\in\mathbb R}(\ell_i(\theta,c))Mi‚Äã=argmaxŒ∏‚ààP,c‚ààR‚Äã(‚Ñìi‚Äã(Œ∏,c)) is concave.

ü§îLemma: CoreFed determines a core-stable predictor in a federated learning setting training classification with logistic regression.

Approximate Core-Stability in DNN

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 2 Possible Parallelization Idea
entry.content:
Some ideas from Maximilian.

Recap Pseudo Code

Look at the Pseudo code again:

Input: KG K:‚ü®E,R,F‚ü©\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:‚ü®E,R,F‚ü©, triple xhrt=(h,r,t)‚ààFx_{hrt}=(h,r,t)\in\mathcal Fxhrt‚Äã=(h,r,t)‚ààF, embedding score function s:E√óR√óE‚ÜíRs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:E√óR√óE‚ÜíR, sample size k‚ààNk\in\mathbb Nk‚ààN

Output: ReliKLB(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})ReliKLB‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã) or ReliKApx(xhrt)ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})ReliKApx‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)

  1. SH‚ÜêS_H\getsSH‚Äã‚Üê sample kkk triples from N‚àí(h)\mathcal N^-(h)N‚àí(h); ST‚ÜêS_T\getsST‚Äã‚Üê sample kkk triples from N‚àí(t)N^-(t)N‚àí(t).

  2. rankH‚Üê1rank_H\gets1rankH‚Äã‚Üê1; rankT‚Üê1rank_T\gets1rankT‚Äã‚Üê1

  3. for xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚ààSH‚à™STx_{h'r't'}\in S_H\cup S_Txh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚Äã‚ààSH‚Äã‚à™ST‚Äã do

    • If s(xhrt)‚â§s(xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤)s(x_{hrt})\le s(x_{h'r't'})s(xhrt‚Äã)‚â§s(xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚Äã) then

      • if h‚Ä≤=hh'=hh‚Ä≤=h then

        rankH‚ÜêrankH+1rank_H\gets rank_H+1rankH‚Äã‚ÜêrankH‚Äã+1

      • if t‚Ä≤=tt'=tt‚Ä≤=t then

        rankT‚ÜêrankT+1rank_T\gets rank_T+1rankT‚Äã‚ÜêrankT‚Äã+1

  4. return 12(1rankH+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚à£+1rankT+‚à£N‚àí(t)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚à£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right)21‚Äã(rankH‚Äã+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£1‚Äã+rankT‚Äã+‚à£N‚àí(t)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£1‚Äã) for ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLB‚Äã

    or 12(1rankHN‚àí(h)‚à£SH‚à£+1rankTN‚àí(t)‚à£ST‚à£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right)21‚Äã(rankH‚Äã‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£N‚àí(h)‚Äã1‚Äã+rankT‚Äã‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£N‚àí(t)‚Äã1‚Äã) for ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApx‚Äã

Ideas for Parallelization

Idea 1 Parallel Sampling

Sampling the negative sets SHS_HSH‚Äã and STS_TST‚Äã can be done in parallel for both head and tail entities. GPU-based libraries like PyTorch can handle large-scale sampling efficiently on GPUs.

I will think about it.

Idea 2 Rank Update

For each sampled triple xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤x_{h'r't'}xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚Äã, it can be parallelized across all samples in SH‚à™STS_H\cup S_TSH‚Äã‚à™ST‚Äã. For-parallel

GPUs are very efficient at handling this kind of parallel computation, especially with batched matrix operations.

‚úÖI will be working on this.

Will there be some write-after-write or read-after-write issues? Should I add some write-lock?

entry.title: Efficient ReliK 1 Paper Reading
entry.content:
This is one of the two projects I undertake in 24 Fall semester, which is related to data mining.

Supervisor: Assoc. Prof. Davide Mottin, PhD Student Maximilian Egger.

Generally speaking, they have already developed a new method, ReliK, for measuring knowledge graph embeddings, but they want to speed it up with GPUs.

So my project is focusing on this. I wish to speed them up with some tolerance on small accuracy loss.

I need to first get familiar with the paper, ReliK: A Reliability Measure for Knowledge Graph Embedding. Here is some digest and notes from it.

Abstract

Object of ReliK: To assess a priori how well a knowledge graph embedding (KGE) will perform on a downstream task and in a specific part of the knowledge graph.

ReliK aka Reliability measure of KGEs.

  • It relies only on KGE embedding scores.
  • Task independent
  • KGE independent

Correlates well with some downstream tasks:

  • tail/relation prediction, triple classification
  • rule mining, question answering.

Introduction

KGE: generate a vector representation for entities and relationships of a KG.

Motivation: KEG method depends on which downstream task. We want to unified, global measure to quantify the reliability of KGE method.

Contributions: ReliK, principled measure that quantifies the reliability of how a KEG will perform will on a certain downstream task in a specific part of the KG without executing that task or training KG!!!

ReliK is based on the relative ranking of existing KG triples w.r.t. non-existing one.

Preliminaries

Knowledge Graph

KG K:‚ü®E,R,F‚ü©\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:‚ü®E,R,F‚ü© is a triple consisting of a set E\mathcal EE of nnn entities, a set R\mathcal RR of relationships, and a set F‚äÇE√óR√óE\mathcal F\subset\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal EF‚äÇE√óR√óE of mmm facts.

A fact is a triple xhrt=(h,r,t)x_{hrt}=(h,r,t)xhrt‚Äã=(h,r,t). head, relation, tail.

We say xhrtx_{hrt}xhrt‚Äã is positive if it actually exists in the KG xhrt‚ààFx_{hrt}\in\mathcal Fxhrt‚Äã‚ààF, negative otherwise xhrt‚ààÃ∏Fx_{hrt}\not\in\mathcal Fxhrt‚ÄãÓÄ†‚ààF.

Knowledge Graph Embedding

It is a representation of entities and relationships in a ddd-dimensional space, d‚â™‚à£E‚à£d\ll\vert\mathcal E\vertd‚â™‚à£E‚à£. The Rd\mathbb R^dRd or Cd\mathbb C^dCd space.

The embedding score: function s:E√óR√óE‚ÜíRs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:E√óR√óE‚ÜíR, which quantifies how like a triple xhrtx_{hrt}xhrt‚Äã exists in K\mathcal KK based on the embedding of its head, relationship, and tail.

  • Intuitively, the higher s(xhrt)s(x_{hrt})s(xhrt‚Äã), the more likely the existence of xhrtx_{hrt}xhrt‚Äã in K\mathcal KK.

Key Reliability

Desideratum

  1. Embedding-agnostic. It is independent of the specific KGE method.
  2. Learning-free. No further KGE training.
  3. Task-agnostic. It is independent of downstream task.
  4. Locality. A good predictor of KGE performance locally to a given triple.

ReliK Measure

To fulfill 1. 2.: Treat embedding score as a black-box function that provides only an indication of the actual existence of a triple.

Use position of a triple via a ranking based on embedding score: Assume the relative ranking of a positive triple to be higher than that of negative.

For 4. locality, we assume that a local approach that consider triples relative to a neighborhood is more appropriate.

Definition

For a triple xhrt=(h,r,t)x_{hrt}=(h,r,t)xhrt‚Äã=(h,r,t) we compute the neighbor set N‚àí(h)\mathcal N^-(h)N‚àí(h) of all possible negative triples, that is triples with head hhh that do not exist in K\mathcal KK.

Similarly, we define N‚àí(t)\mathcal N^-(t)N‚àí(t) for tail.

Head rank: rankH(xhrt)=‚à£{x‚ààN‚àí(h):s(x)>s(xhrt)}‚à£+1rank_H(x_{hrt})=|\{x\in\mathcal N^-(h):s(x)\gt s(x_{hrt})\}|+1rankH‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)=‚à£{x‚ààN‚àí(h):s(x)>s(xhrt‚Äã)}‚à£+1

Similarly, we define rankT(xhrt)rank_T(x_{hrt})rankT‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã) for tail.

ReliK(xhrt)=12(1rankH(xhrt)+1rankT(xhrt)).ReliK(x_{hrt})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H(x_{hrt})}+\frac{1}{rank_T(x_{hrt})}\right).ReliK(xhrt‚Äã)=21‚Äã(rankH‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)1‚Äã+rankT‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)1‚Äã).

ReliK can easily be extended from single triples to sub-graphs by computing the average reliability among the triples in the subgraph.

We define the ReliK score of a set S‚äÜFS\subseteq\mathcal FS‚äÜF of triples as

ReliK(S)=1S‚àëxhrt‚ààSReliK(xhrt).ReliK(S)=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{x_{hrt}\in S}ReliK(x_{hrt}).ReliK(S)=S1‚Äãxhrt‚Äã‚ààS‚àë‚ÄãReliK(xhrt‚Äã).

ReliK‚àà(0,1]ReliK\in(0,1]ReliK‚àà(0,1]. The higher the ReliKReliKReliK, the better reliability.

The lower the head-rank and tail-rank, the better the ranking of xhrtx_{hrt}xhrt‚Äã induced by the underlying embedding scores.

Efficiently Computing ReliK

Computing original ReliK requires Œ©(‚à£C‚à£‚ãÖ‚à£R‚à£)\Omega(|\mathcal C|\cdot|\mathcal R|)Œ©(‚à£C‚à£‚ãÖ‚à£R‚à£), as it needs to scan the entire negative neighborhood of the target triple.

Computationally TOO HEAVY!!!

We thus propose approximate version of ReliK with efficiency.

Main intuition of approximation is that the precise ranking of many potential triples is not needed.

What it matters is just the number of those triples that exhibit a higher embedding score than the target triple.

Lower bound:

  • ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLB‚Äã, a lower bound to ReliKReliKReliK by counting the negative triples in the sample that have a lower embedding score.

Approximate

  • ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApx‚Äã, estimation of ReliKReliKReliK by evaluating the fraction of triples in the sample that have a higher score than the triple under consideration and scaling this fraction to the total number of negative triples.

Let SHS_HSH‚Äã be a random subset of kkk elements selected without replacement independently and uniformly at random from negative neighborhood N‚àí(h)\mathcal N^-(h)N‚àí(h) of the head hhh of a triple xhrtx_{hrt}xhrt‚Äã.

rankHS(xhrt)=‚à£{x‚ààSH:s(x)>s(xhrt)}‚à£+1,rank_H^S(x_{hrt})=\vert\{x\in S_H:s(x)\gt s(x_{hrt})\}\vert+1,rankHS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)=‚à£{x‚ààSH‚Äã:s(x)>s(xhrt‚Äã)}‚à£+1,

to be the rank of the score s(xhrt)s(x_{hrt})s(xhrt‚Äã) the KGE assigns to xhrtx_{hrt}xhrt‚Äã, among all the triples in the sample.

Similarly, we compute rankTSrank_T^SrankTS‚Äã for tail‚Äôs neighborhood N‚àí(t)\mathcal N^-(t)N‚àí(t).

Lower Bound Estimator

rankH(xhrt)‚â§rankHS(xhrt)+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚à£rankT(xhrt)‚â§rankTS(xhrt)+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚à£‚áíReliKLB(xhrt)=12(1rankHS(xhrt)+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚à£+1rankTS(xhrt)+‚à£N‚àí(t)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚à£),rank_H(x_{hrt})\le rank_H^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|\\rank_T(x_{hrt})\le rank_T^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_T|\\\Rarr ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T^S(x_{hrt})+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right),rankH‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)‚â§rankHS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£rankT‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)‚â§rankTS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£‚áíReliKLB‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)=21‚Äã(rankHS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£1‚Äã+rankTS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)+‚à£N‚àí(t)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£1‚Äã),

It holds that ReliKLB(xhrt)‚â§ReliK(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})\le ReliK(x_{hrt})ReliKLB‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)‚â§ReliK(xhrt‚Äã).

Upper Bound Estimator

Theoretical analysis is omitted here.

ReliKApx(xhrt)=12(1rankHS(xhrt)N‚àí(h)‚à£SH‚à£+1rankTS(xhrt)N‚àí(t)‚à£ST‚à£).ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H^S(x_{hrt})\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T^S(x_{hrt})\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right).ReliKApx‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)=21‚Äã‚éù‚éõ‚ÄãrankHS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£N‚àí(h)‚Äã1‚Äã+rankTS‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£N‚àí(t)‚Äã1‚Äã‚é†‚éû‚Äã.

Pseudo Code

Input: KG K:‚ü®E,R,F‚ü©\mathcal K:\langle\mathcal E,\mathcal R,\mathcal F\rangleK:‚ü®E,R,F‚ü©, triple xhrt=(h,r,t)‚ààFx_{hrt}=(h,r,t)\in\mathcal Fxhrt‚Äã=(h,r,t)‚ààF, embedding score function s:E√óR√óE‚ÜíRs:\mathcal E\times\mathcal R\times\mathcal E\to\mathbb Rs:E√óR√óE‚ÜíR, sample size k‚ààNk\in\mathbb Nk‚ààN

Output: ReliKLB(xhrt)ReliK_{LB}(x_{hrt})ReliKLB‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã) or ReliKApx(xhrt)ReliK_{Apx}(x_{hrt})ReliKApx‚Äã(xhrt‚Äã)

  1. SH‚ÜêS_H\getsSH‚Äã‚Üê sample kkk triples from N‚àí(h)\mathcal N^-(h)N‚àí(h); ST‚ÜêS_T\getsST‚Äã‚Üê sample kkk triples from N‚àí(t)N^-(t)N‚àí(t).

  2. rankH‚Üê1rank_H\gets1rankH‚Äã‚Üê1; rankT‚Üê1rank_T\gets1rankT‚Äã‚Üê1

  3. for xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚ààSH‚à™STx_{h'r't'}\in S_H\cup S_Txh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚Äã‚ààSH‚Äã‚à™ST‚Äã do

    • If s(xhrt)‚â§s(xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤)s(x_{hrt})\le s(x_{h'r't'})s(xhrt‚Äã)‚â§s(xh‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤t‚Ä≤‚Äã) then

      • if h‚Ä≤=hh'=hh‚Ä≤=h then

        rankH‚ÜêrankH+1rank_H\gets rank_H+1rankH‚Äã‚ÜêrankH‚Äã+1

      • if t‚Ä≤=tt'=tt‚Ä≤=t then

        rankT‚ÜêrankT+1rank_T\gets rank_T+1rankT‚Äã‚ÜêrankT‚Äã+1

  4. return 12(1rankH+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚à£+1rankT+‚à£N‚àí(t)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚à£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H+|\mathcal N^-(h)|-|S_H|}+\frac{1}{rank_T+|\mathcal N^-(t)|-|S_T|}\right)21‚Äã(rankH‚Äã+‚à£N‚àí(h)‚à£‚àí‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£1‚Äã+rankT‚Äã+‚à£N‚àí(t)‚à£‚àí‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£1‚Äã) for ReliKLBReliK_{LB}ReliKLB‚Äã

    or 12(1rankHN‚àí(h)‚à£SH‚à£+1rankTN‚àí(t)‚à£ST‚à£)\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{rank_H\frac{\mathcal N^-(h)}{|S_H|}}+\frac{1}{rank_T\frac{\mathcal N^-(t)}{|S_T|}}\right)21‚Äã(rankH‚Äã‚à£SH‚Äã‚à£N‚àí(h)‚Äã1‚Äã+rankT‚Äã‚à£ST‚Äã‚à£N‚àí(t)‚Äã1‚Äã) for ReliKApxReliK_{Apx}ReliKApx‚Äã

Time Complexity

O(k)\mathcal O(k)O(k).

When k‚âà20%‚ãÖnk\approx 20\%\cdot nk‚âà20%‚ãÖn, 2.5X faster, mean square error = 0.002.

entry.title: ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂíåËÆ°ÁÆóÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ 8 Branching Programs and Barrington‚Äôs Theorem
entry.content:
NC1‚äÜL/poly‚äÜNL/poly‚äÜAC1NC^1\subseteq L/poly\subseteq NL/poly\subseteq AC^1NC1‚äÜL/poly‚äÜNL/poly‚äÜAC1.

The model of branching programs that give a precise characterization of L/polyL/polyL/poly and NL/polyNL/polyNL/poly.

Deterministic / non-deterministic branching program

Boolean Branching Program

Deterministic

üìñDefinition 32. A Deterministic Boolean branching program BBB with nnn inputs consists of the following:

  • A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A), where the out-degree of all nodes is in {0,1,2}\{0,1,2\}{0,1,2}.
  • A partial labeling ‚ÑìV:V‚Üí{0,1,x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn}\ell_V:V\to\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}‚ÑìV‚Äã:V‚Üí{0,1,x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã} of the nodes of DDD.
  • A partial labeling ‚ÑìA:A‚Üí{0,1}\ell_A:A\to\{0,1\}‚ÑìA‚Äã:A‚Üí{0,1} of the edges of DDD.
  • An initial node s‚ààVs\in Vs‚ààV.

When node vvv is not labeled by ‚ÑìV\ell_V‚ÑìV‚Äã, we say that vvv is dummy.

If ‚ÑìV(v)‚àà{0,1}\ell_V(v)\in\{0,1\}‚ÑìV‚Äã(v)‚àà{0,1}, we say that vvv is an output node.

The graph DDD and the labeling function ‚ÑìV,‚ÑìA\ell_V,\ell_A‚ÑìV‚Äã,‚ÑìA‚Äã should satisfy:

  1. The node sss is not a dummy node.
  2. If ‚ÑìV(v)‚àà{x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn}\ell_V(v)\in\{x_1,\cdots,x_n\}‚ÑìV‚Äã(v)‚àà{x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã}, the out-degree of vvv is 222, and one outgoing edges of vvv is labeled 000 and 111 by ‚ÑìA\ell_A‚ÑìA‚Äã respectively.
  3. If ‚ÑìV(v)‚àà{0,1}\ell_V(v)\in\{0,1\}‚ÑìV‚Äã(v)‚àà{0,1}, i.e., vvv is an output node, the out-degree of vvv is 000.
  4. If vvv is a dummy node, the in-degree of vvv is not 000, the out-degree of vvv is 111.

A branching program with nnn inputs compute a Boolean function f:{0,1}n‚Üí{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}n‚Üí{0,1} in a natural way.

Given an input x‚àà{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx‚àà{0,1}n, start in the initial node sss, follow a path to an output node, thereby giving the value of f(x)f(x)f(x).

When passing through dummy node, directly go through the unique path.

When passing through labeled node, go to 111-labeled edge if xi=1x_i=1xi‚Äã=1, 000-labeled edge if xi=0x_i=0xi‚Äã=0.

Non-deterministic

Simply modify the deterministic branching program:

  • label of vertices is ‚ÑìV:V‚Üí{0,1,‚àó,x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn}\ell_V:V\to\{0,1,*,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}‚ÑìV‚Äã:V‚Üí{0,1,‚àó,x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã}. If ‚ÑìV(v)=‚àó\ell_V(v)=*‚ÑìV‚Äã(v)=‚àó, vvv is called a choice node.
  • We require the out-degree of vvv is 222 and outgoing edges are not labeled by ‚ÑìA\ell_A‚ÑìA‚Äã.

For a given input x‚àà{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx‚àà{0,1}n, traverse the branching program from sss, but at a choice node choose to follow an arbitrary arc.

We say that the non-deterministic branching program accepts xxx if there exist such choices leading the path to an output node labeled 111.

üìñDefinition 33. The size of a branching program is the number of nodes in the branching program. The length of a branching program is the length of the longest path from sss to a node to out degree 000.

Then define complexity classes of languages computed by size-bounded branching programs.

üìñDefinition 34. Let S:N‚ÜíNS:\mathbb N\to\mathbb NS:N‚ÜíN. BPSIZE(S(n))BPSIZE(S(n))BPSIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of deterministic Boolean branching program of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)). Similarly, NPBSIZE(S(n))NPBSIZE(S(n))NPBSIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of non-deterministic Boolean branching program of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).

ü§îTheorem 43. L/poly=BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(nO(1))L/poly=BPSIZE(n^{O(1)}),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(n^{O(1)})L/poly=BPSIZE(nO(1)),NL/poly=NBPSIZE(nO(1)).

ü§îTheorem 44. L=UL‚àíBPSIZE(nO(1)),NL=UL‚àíNBPSIZE(nO(1))L=U_L-BPSIZE(n^{O(1)}),NL=U_L-NBPSIZE(n^{O(1)})L=UL‚Äã‚àíBPSIZE(nO(1)),NL=UL‚Äã‚àíNBPSIZE(nO(1)).

Programs over Monoids and Bounded Width Branching Programs

monoid Âê´Âπ∫ÂçäÁæ§

What if we restrict the width of branching programs?

Consider the width to be constant.

üìñDefinition 35. A branching program BBB is in layered form, if there is a partition of the nodes of BBB into layers V1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Vl,V=V1‚à™‚ãØ‚à™VlV_1,\cdots ,V_l,V=V_1\cup\cdots\cup V_lV1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Vl‚Äã,V=V1‚Äã‚à™‚ãØ‚à™Vl‚Äã, in such a way that every edge go between some pair of adjacent layers ViV_iVi‚Äã and Vi+1V_{i+1}Vi+1‚Äã.

üìñDefinition 36. The width of a branching program with partition into layers V=V1‚à™‚ãØ‚à™VlV=V_1\cup\cdots\cup V_lV=V1‚Äã‚à™‚ãØ‚à™Vl‚Äã is the size of the largest layer, maxi‚à£Vi‚à£max_i|V_i|maxi‚Äã‚à£Vi‚Äã‚à£.

Then here comes new complexity classes.

üìñDefinition 37. BWBPBWBPBWBP is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean branching programs polynomial size and width O(1)O(1)O(1).

It‚Äôs easy to show AC0‚äÜBWBPAC^0\subseteq BWBPAC0‚äÜBWBP (‚ùì)

Conjecture: MAJ‚ààÃ∏BWBPMAJ\not\in BWBPMAJÓÄ†‚ààBWBP.

Fact: BWBP=NC1BWBP=NC^1BWBP=NC1.

Consider computation over finite algebraic structures, finite groups.

üìñDefinition 38. A monoid is a set MMM closed under an associative binary operation s.t. MMM has an identity element:

  1. For all x,y‚ààMx,y\in Mx,y‚ààM, we have xy‚ààMxy\in Mxy‚ààM. Â∞ÅÈó≠ÊÄß
  2. For all x,y,z‚ààMx,y,z\in Mx,y,z‚ààM, we have x(yz)=(xy)zx(yz)=(xy)zx(yz)=(xy)z. ÁªìÂêàÂæã
  3. There is an element 1‚ààM1\in M1‚ààM s.t. 1x=x1=x1x=x1=x1x=x1=x for all x‚ààMx\in Mx‚ààM Âê´ÊúâÂπ∫ÂÖÉ

The set of functions from a set SSS to itself which forms a monoid, denoted TST_STS‚Äã.

The set of partial functions from a set SSS to itself forms a monoid, denote PTSPT_SPTS‚Äã.

Commonsense: Any group is a monoid.

üìñDefinition 39. Let MMM be a finite monoid. A program PPP over MMM with nnn inputs consists of the following:

  1. A sequence I1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,IlI_1,\cdots,I_lI1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Il‚Äã of triples of the form ‚ü®i,g0,g1‚ü©\langle i,g_0,g_1\rangle‚ü®i,g0‚Äã,g1‚Äã‚ü©, where i‚àà{1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,n}i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}i‚àà{1,‚ãØ,n} and g0,g1‚ààMg_0,g_1\in Mg0‚Äã,g1‚Äã‚ààM.
  2. An accepting set A‚äÜMA\subseteq MA‚äÜM.

The triples is called instructions of the program PPP.

A program PPP over MMM with nnn inputs define a Boolean function f:{0,1}n‚Üí{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}f:{0,1}n‚Üí{0,1} in a natural way:

  • Let x‚àà{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx‚àà{0,1}n.
  • The output of an instruction I=‚ü®i,g0,g1‚ü©I=\langle i,g_0,g_1\rangleI=‚ü®i,g0‚Äã,g1‚Äã‚ü© is given by I(x)=gxiI(x)=g_{x_i}I(x)=gxi‚Äã‚Äã.
  • The output of the program is P(x)=‚àèj=1lIj(x)P(x)=\prod_{j=1}^lI_j(x)P(x)=‚àèj=1l‚ÄãIj‚Äã(x).
  • Finally f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 iff P(x)‚ààAP(x)\in AP(x)‚ààA.

üìñDefinition 40. The length of a program PPP is the number of instructions of PPP.

ü§îProposition 10: Let fff be a Boolean function computed by a family of polynomial length programs over a finite monoid MMM. Then f‚ààNC1f\in NC^1f‚ààNC1.

ü§îProposition 11. BWBP‚äÜNC1BWBP\subseteq NC^1BWBP‚äÜNC1.

Barrington‚Äôs Theorem

Any language in NC1NC^1NC1 can be computed by polynomial size constant width branching programs.

Theorem 45 (Barrington‚Äôs Theorem). BWBP=NC1BWBP=NC^1BWBP=NC1.

By constructing polynomial length programs over group S5S_5S5‚Äã of permutations of 555 elements.

The width is fixed 555.

We denote the identity permutation by e‚ààS5e\in S_5e‚ààS5‚Äã.

üìñDefinition 41. Let PPP be a program over S5S_5S5‚Äã and let œÉ‚ààS5\sigma\in S_5œÉ‚ààS5‚Äã be a 555-cycle. We say that PPP œÉ\sigmaœÉ-computes a Boolean function fff if P(x)=œÉP(x)=\sigmaP(x)=œÉ when f(x)=1f(x)=1f(x)=1 and P(x)=eP(x)=eP(x)=e when f(x)=0f(x)=0f(x)=0. We can also simply say that PPP 555-cycle computes fff.

ü§îLemma. Let œÉ\sigmaœÉ and œÑ\tauœÑ be 555-cycles. If a program PPP over S5S_5S5‚Äã of length lll œÉ\sigmaœÉ-computes fff, then there is another program P‚Ä≤P'P‚Ä≤ of length lll over S5S_5S5‚Äã that œÑ\tauœÑ-computes fff.

ü§îLemma. If a program PPP over S5S_5S5‚Äã of length lll 555-cycle computes fff, then there is another program P‚Ä≤P'P‚Ä≤ of length lll that 555-cycle computes ¬¨f\neg f¬¨f.

üìñDefinition 42 (commutator ‰∫§Êç¢Â≠ê). Let GGG be a group and g,h‚ààGg,h\in Gg,h‚ààG. The commutator [g,h][g,h][g,h] is the element g‚àí1h‚àí1ghg^{-1}h^{-1}ghg‚àí1h‚àí1gh.

ü§îLemma. There exists 555-cycles œÉ1\sigma_1œÉ1‚Äã and œÉ2\sigma_2œÉ2‚Äã s.t. their commutator [œÉ1,œÉ2][\sigma_1,\sigma_2][œÉ1‚Äã,œÉ2‚Äã], is also a 555-cycle.

œÉ1=(1,2,3,4,5),œÉ2=(1,3,5,4,2).\sigma_1=(1,2,3,4,5),\sigma_2=(1,3,5,4,2).œÉ1‚Äã=(1,2,3,4,5),œÉ2‚Äã=(1,3,5,4,2).

[œÉ1,œÉ2]=(1,2,5,3,4)[\sigma_1,\sigma_2]=(1,2,5,3,4)[œÉ1‚Äã,œÉ2‚Äã]=(1,2,5,3,4)

ü§îProposition 12. Let CCC be a fanin 222 circuit of depth ddd. Then there exist a program PPP of length at most 4d4^d4d that 555-cycle computes the output of CCC.

By Proposition 11 and 12, we obtain Barrington‚Äôs Theorem.

  • interesserer sig for ‚Ä¶ ÂØπ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ÊÑüÂÖ¥Ë∂£
  • er grove mod ‚Ä¶ ÂØπ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ÂæàÁ≤óÈ≤Å
  1. ÈÉ®ÂàÜÂõ∫ÂÆöÊê≠ÈÖçÂèØ‰ª•Âä†Êüê‰∫ãÔºàÂêçËØç„ÄÅ‰ª£ËØçÔºâÔºåÂ∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØÈÇ£‰∫õÊèèËø∞Êú∫‰ºöÔºåÈóÆÈ¢òÊàñÊÉÖÊÑüÁöÑË°®Ëææ„ÄÇ
  2. ÈÉ®ÂàÜÂõ∫ÂÆöÊê≠ÈÖçÂèØ‰ª•Âä†Êüê‰∫∫ÔºåÈÄöÂ∏∏Ë°®Ëææ‰∫∫‰∏é‰∫∫‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÊÉÖÊÑüÊàñÊÄÅÂ∫¶ÁöÑÁü≠ËØ≠„ÄÇ
  3. ÂæàÂ§öÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÂõ∫ÂÆöÊê≠ÈÖçÂêéÈù¢‰ºöË∑ü at + Âä®ËØç‰∏çÂÆöÂºè„ÄÇ

Âè£ËØ≠Ë°®ËææÁªÉ‰π† Mit m√∏de med dansk kultur

Jeg oplevede dansk kultur for f√∏rste gang, da jeg kom til Danmark for at studere. Jeg har lagt m√¶rke til flere forskelle og ligheder mellem Danmark og mit hjemland. For eksempel bruger man i mit hjemland ofte ‚ÄòDe‚Äô, n√•r man taler med √¶ldre eller folk, man ikke kender godt. I Danmark siger man bare ‚Äòdu‚Äô til alle, og det g√∏r, at folk f√∏ler sig mere lige. Det synes jeg er meget sp√¶ndende.

En anden stor forskel er tillid. I Danmark stoler folk meget p√• hinanden. Man ser ofte, at folk efterlader deres ting udenfor, uden at v√¶re bange for, at de bliver stj√•let. I mit hjemland er vi mere forsigtige, fordi vi ikke har samme tillid. Jeg synes, det er godt, at der er s√• meget tillid her.

Noget andet, jeg har lagt m√¶rke til, er m√•den, danskerne kommunikerer p√•. I mit hjemland bruger vi ofte meget kropssprog, mens danskerne er mere rolige. Men de siger, hvad de mener, og det kan v√¶re lidt overraskende i starten. Jeg har ogs√• l√¶rt, at lighed er meget vigtigt i Danmark. B√•de m√¶nd og kvinder deler husarbejde og b√∏rnepasning, hvilket er anderledes fra mit hjemland.

Hygge er ogs√• noget, der er meget typisk dansk. Det handler om at skabe en hyggelig og afslappet stemning, ofte med venner og familie. I mit hjemland er socialisering mere h√∏jlydt og aktiv, s√• hygge har v√¶ret en ny oplevelse for mig. Men jeg kan godt lide det.

Til sidst har jeg lagt m√¶rke til, at danskerne ikke altid er s√• gode til at tale om problemer. De vil hellere undg√• konflikter, hvilket er noget, jeg har skullet v√¶nne mig til. Men jeg synes, det er godt, at danskerne g√•r op i tolerance og respekt for hinanden. Alle bliver behandlet p√• samme m√•de, og det er noget, jeg virkelig har l√¶rt at s√¶tte pris p√•.
