entry.title: Fair AI/ML 0 Overview
entry.content:
This semester, I will do a project again with Iannis.

I took some time to review the tutorial Fairness in AI/ML via Social Choice by Evi Micha & Nisarg Shah.

Social Choice Theory: Aggregating individual preferences into ‚Äúgood‚Äù collective decisions

Fairness in Social Choice

ÂæàÁÜüÊÇâ‰∫ÜÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âø´ÈÄüÊé†Ëøá„ÄÇ

‚ö†Ô∏èËøôÈáåËÄÉËôëÁöÑÊòØ DIVISIBLE ITEMS.

EF, PROP

Fair division: Agents NNN, divisible resources MMM, utility function uiu_iui‚Äã.

Non-negative utilities (good), non-positive utilities (chores).

Proportionality, envy-freeness.

The Core

A core is a subset of agents, among which they can redistribute their entitlements.

But redistributed entitlements shouldn‚Äôt be a Pareto improvement.

2 types of the core

  1. Resource-scaling version

    No group of agents SSS should be able to find any allocation BBB of their proportionally entitled share of the resources that is Pareto improvement.

    ‚àÉÃ∏S‚äÜN,‚à£S‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚ãÖM‚ÜíB:ui(Bi)>ui(Ai)‚àÄi‚ààS\not\exist S\subseteq N,\frac{|S|}{|N|}\cdot M\to B:u_i(B_i)\gt u_i(A_i)\forall i\in SÓÄ†‚àÉS‚äÜN,‚à£N‚à£‚à£S‚à£‚Äã‚ãÖM‚ÜíB:ui‚Äã(Bi‚Äã)>ui‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)‚àÄi‚ààS

  2. Utility-scaling version

    No group of agents SSS should be able to find any allocation BBB of the resources that is a Pareto improvement even after proportional utility-scaling.

    ‚àÉÃ∏S‚äÜN,M‚ÜíB:‚à£S‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚ãÖui(Bi)>ui(Ai)‚àÄi‚ààS\not\exist S\subseteq N,M\to B:\frac{|S|}{|N|}\cdot u_i(B_i)\gt u_i(A_i)\forall i\in SÓÄ†‚àÉS‚äÜN,M‚ÜíB:‚à£N‚à£‚à£S‚à£‚Äã‚ãÖui‚Äã(Bi‚Äã)>ui‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)‚àÄi‚ààS

  • Two versions are equivalent for some setting.
  • They are different when utilities are not linear additive.
  • If there is no scalable resource, there is no way to define resource-scaling version. But it is more appealing.

Nash Social Welfare

NSW is geometric mean of agent utilities.

NSW(A)=(‚àèi‚ààNui(Ai))1/‚à£N‚à£NSW(A)=\left(\prod_{i\in N}u_i(A_i)\right)^{1/|N|}NSW(A)=(i‚ààN‚àè‚Äãui‚Äã(Ai‚Äã))1/‚à£N‚à£

There are some other welfare functions:

  • Utilitarian social welfare: USW(A)=1‚à£N‚à£‚ãÖ‚àëi‚ààNui(Ai)USW(A)=\frac{1}{|N|}\cdot\sum_{i\in N}u_i(A_i)USW(A)=‚à£N‚à£1‚Äã‚ãÖ‚àëi‚ààN‚Äãui‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)

    ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàË¶ÅËµ∑Ëøô‰πàÊÄ™ÁöÑÂêçÂ≠óÔºåÂè´ average social welfare ‰∏çÂ•ΩÂòõÔºÅ

  • Egalitarian social welfare: ESW(A)=min‚Å°i‚ààNui(Ai)ESW(A)=\min_{i\in N}u_i(A_i)ESW(A)=mini‚ààN‚Äãui‚Äã(Ai‚Äã)

    ÊòéÊòéÂèØ‰ª•Âè´ least social welfare ÁöÑ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

ü§îTheorem [Varian '74]: Any allocation maximizing NSW is envy-free in the core.

ü§îTheorem [Orlin '10]: An allocation maximizing the NSW can be computed in strongly polynomial time.

Application of Core: Committee Selection

There are set of voters NNN, set of candidates MMM.

Each agent iii approves a subset of candidates Ai‚äÜMA_i\subseteq MAi‚Äã‚äÜM.

  • The utility for each voter is defined as the number of intersection of committee member and its approval.

    ui(W)=‚à£W‚à©Ai‚à£u_i(W)=|W\cap A_i|ui‚Äã(W)=‚à£W‚à©Ai‚Äã‚à£

  • The goal is to find W‚äÜMW\subseteq MW‚äÜM with ‚à£W‚à£‚â§k|W|\le k‚à£W‚à£‚â§k with given kkk.

WWW is in the core if there is no S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN and T‚äÜMT\subseteq MT‚äÜM with ‚à£T‚à£‚â§‚à£S‚à£‚à£N‚à£‚ãÖk|T|\le\frac{|S|}{|N|}\cdot k‚à£T‚à£‚â§‚à£N‚à£‚à£S‚à£‚Äã‚ãÖk (Here the candidates are resources, so its resource-scaling version) s.t. ui(T)>ui(W)‚àÄi‚ààSu_i(T)\gt u_i(W)\forall i\in Sui‚Äã(T)>ui‚Äã(W)‚àÄi‚ààS.

Advantages

It‚Äôs broadly defined

  • It often depends only on the definition of AGENTS and PREFERENCES.
  • Applicable to any setting as long as you define these two pieces of information.

Notions such as the core achieve group fairness to all possible groups.

  • No need to pre-specify the groups.
  • scale automatically with group size and cohesiveness, without additional parameters.

Envy-Freeness in ML

Classification

The model

  • Population of individuals given by a distribution DDD over XXX.

    individual iii represent data point xi‚ààXx_i\in Xxi‚Äã‚ààX.

  • Classifier f:X‚ÜíYf:X\to Yf:X‚ÜíY maps every individual to a classification outcome

Types of classification:

  • Hard binary
  • Hard multi-class
  • Soft binary
  • Soft multi-class

Objective: minimize loss function

Utility function should be somehow related to loss function.

How to measure fairness in ML?

Individual Fairness

[Dwork, Hardt, Pitassi, Reingold, Zemel, 2012]

Similar individuals should be treated similarly

Classifier fff is individual fair if

‚àÄx,y‚ààN,D(f(x),f(y))‚â§d(x,y)\forall x,y\in N,D(f(x),f(y))\le d(x,y)‚àÄx,y‚ààN,D(f(x),f(y))‚â§d(x,y)

Envy-Freeness

[Balcan, Dick, Noothigattu, Procaccia, 2019]

Equal individuals shouldn‚Äôt envy each other.

Classifier fff is envy-free if

‚àÄx,y‚ààN,ux(f(x))‚â•ux(f(y))\forall x,y\in N,u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(f(y))‚àÄx,y‚ààN,ux‚Äã(f(x))‚â•ux‚Äã(f(y))

Envy-freeness is too strong for deterministic classifiers

  • loss of optimal deterministic EF classifier ‚â•1\ge1‚â•1.
  • Loss of optimal randomized EF classifier ‚â§1/Œ≥\le1/\gamma‚â§1/Œ≥.

‰∏ÄÁõ¥Ê≤°ÁúãÊáÇËøô‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÂú®ËÆ≤‰∏™Âï•

Preference-Informed IF

[Kim, Korolova, Rothblum, Yona, 2019]

Similar individuals shouldn‚Äôt envy each other too much.

Classifier is PIIF if

\forall x,y\in N,\exist z\in Y,D(z,f(y))\le d(x,y)\and u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(z).

Approximate EF

Equal individuals shouldn‚Äôt envy each other too much.

Classifier fff is approximately EF if ‚àÄx,y‚ààN,ux(f(x))‚â•ux(f(y))‚àíœµ\forall x,y\in N,u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(f(y))-\epsilon‚àÄx,y‚ààN,ux‚Äã(f(x))‚â•ux‚Äã(f(y))‚àíœµ.

OR

Classifier fff is approximately EF if ‚àÄx,y‚ààN,ux(f(x))‚â•ux(f(y))‚àíd(x,y)\forall x,y\in N,u_x(f(x))\ge u_x(f(y))-d(x,y)‚àÄx,y‚ààN,ux‚Äã(f(x))‚â•ux‚Äã(f(y))‚àíd(x,y)

Average Group Envy-Freeness

Equal groups shouldn‚Äôt envy-each other too much on average.

Classifier fff is approximately average group EF w.r.t. groups G1,G2G_1,G_2G1‚Äã,G2‚Äã if

Ex‚àºG1,y‚àºG2[ux(f(y))‚àíux(f(x))]‚â§0\mathbb E_{x\sim G_1,y\sim G_2}[u_x(f(y))-u_x(f(x))]\le 0Ex‚àºG1‚Äã,y‚àºG2‚Äã‚Äã[ux‚Äã(f(y))‚àíux‚Äã(f(x))]‚â§0

Applicable for decision-making with limited resources

  • e.g. deciding on loan or bail applications
  • envy can not be prevented

Can be imposed for several pairs of groups simultaneously

Recommendations

[Do, Corbett-Davies, Atif, Usunier, 2023]

Model

  • Individuals represented by data points in set XXX
  • A set items YYY
  • A set of contexts CCC

Recommendation policy œÄ\piœÄ

  • œÄx(y‚à£c)\pi_x(y|c)œÄx‚Äã(y‚à£c) is probability of recommending item yyy to user xxx given a context ccc.

Utility function: ux(œÄx)=Ec‚àºCm,y‚àºœÄx(‚ãÖ‚à£c)[vx(y‚à£c)]u_x(\pi_x)=\mathbb E_{c\sim C_m,y\sim\pi_x(\cdot|c)}[v_x(y|c)]ux‚Äã(œÄx‚Äã)=Ec‚àºCm‚Äã,y‚àºœÄx‚Äã(‚ãÖ‚à£c)‚Äã[vx‚Äã(y‚à£c)].

Envy-freeness: ‚àÄx,x‚Ä≤‚ààX,ux(œÄx)‚â•ux(œÄx‚Ä≤)‚àíœµ\forall x,x'\in X,u_x(\pi_x)\ge u_x(\pi_{x'})-\epsilon‚àÄx,x‚Ä≤‚ààX,ux‚Äã(œÄx‚Äã)‚â•ux‚Äã(œÄx‚Ä≤‚Äã)‚àíœµ

Two-Sided Fairness

‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØ two-sided Âë¢ÔºüÂõ†‰∏∫ÂèØ‰ª•ÁªôÁî®Êà∑ÂÆö‰πâÊïàÁî®ÂáΩÊï∞Ôºå‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÁªôË¶ÅÊé®ËçêÁöÑÂïÜÂìÅÂÆö‰πâÊïàÁî®ÂáΩÊï∞„ÄÇ

[Biswas, Patro, Ganguly, Gummadi, Chakraborty, 2023]

Many-to-many matching

  • each user is recommended kkk products
  • each product may be recommended to a different number of users

Relevance of products to users given by V:X√óY‚ÜíRV:X\times Y\to\mathbb RV:X√óY‚ÜíR

Recommendation policy œÄ\piœÄ

  • Each user xxx is recommended œÄx‚äÜY\pi_x\subseteq YœÄx‚Äã‚äÜY with ‚à£œÄx‚à£=k|\pi_x|=k‚à£œÄx‚Äã‚à£=k
  • Let Yx‚àóY_x^*Yx‚àó‚Äã be the top-k products for user xxx by relevance

Utilities

  • Utility to user xxx given by ux(œÄx)=‚àëy‚ààœÄxV(x,y)‚àëy‚ààœÄx‚àóV(x,y)u_x(\pi_x)=\frac{\sum_{y\in\pi_x}V(x,y)}{\sum_{y\in\pi_x^*}V(x,y)}ux‚Äã(œÄx‚Äã)=‚àëy‚ààœÄx‚àó‚Äã‚ÄãV(x,y)‚àëy‚ààœÄx‚Äã‚ÄãV(x,y)‚Äã
  • Utility to product yyy given by Ey(œÄ)E_y(\pi)Ey‚Äã(œÄ), the number of users yyy is exposed to

Two-sided fairness

  • Fairness for users: EF1

    ‚àÄx,x‚Ä≤‚ààX,‚àÉy‚ààœÄx‚Ä≤:ux(œÄx)‚â•ux(œÄx‚Ä≤‚ï≤{y})\forall x,x'\in X,\exist y\in\pi_{x'}:u_x(\pi_x)\ge u_x(\pi_{x'}\diagdown\{y\})‚àÄx,x‚Ä≤‚ààX,‚àÉy‚ààœÄx‚Ä≤‚Äã:ux‚Äã(œÄx‚Äã)‚â•ux‚Äã(œÄx‚Ä≤‚Äã‚ï≤{y})

  • Fairness for products: minimum exposure E‚Äæ\overline EE

    ‚àÄy‚ààY,Ey(œÄ)‚â•E‚Äæ\forall y\in Y,E_y(\pi)\ge\overline E‚àÄy‚ààY,Ey‚Äã(œÄ)‚â•E

Theorem: There exists an efficient algorithm that achieves EF1 among all users and the minimum exposure guarantee among at least m‚àíkm-km‚àík products.

Non-Centroid Clustering

[Ahmadi, Awasthi, Khuller, Kleindessner, Morgenstern, Sukprasert, Vakilian, 2022]

[Aamand, Chen, Liu, Silwal, Sukprasert, Vakilian, Zhang, 2023]

Goal: Partition the agents into kkk clusters, i.e., C=(C1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Ck‚Äã)

Model

  • Set of agents NNN partitioned into C=(C1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Ck‚Äã).
  • Cluster containing agent iii denoted by C(i)C(i)C(i).
  • Distance metric d:N√óN‚ÜíR‚â•0d:N\times N\to\mathbb R_{\ge 0}d:N√óN‚ÜíR‚â•0‚Äã.

Œ±\alphaŒ±-EF: For each i‚ààNi\in Ni‚ààN and j‚àà[k]j\in[k]j‚àà[k] with i‚ààÃ∏Cji\not\in C_jiÓÄ†‚ààCj‚Äã: either C(i)=iC(i)=iC(i)=i or

1‚à£C(i)‚à£‚àí1‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààC(i)d(i,i‚Ä≤)‚â§Œ±‚à£Cj‚à£‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààCjd(i,i‚Ä≤)\frac{1}{|C(i)|-1}\sum_{i'\in C(i)}d(i,i')\le\frac{\alpha}{|C_j|}\sum_{i'\in C_j}d(i,i')‚à£C(i)‚à£‚àí11‚Äãi‚Ä≤‚ààC(i)‚àë‚Äãd(i,i‚Ä≤)‚â§‚à£Cj‚Äã‚à£Œ±‚Äãi‚Ä≤‚ààCj‚Äã‚àë‚Äãd(i,i‚Ä≤)

Theorem:

A 1-envy-free clustering does not always exist, but an O(1)O(1)O(1)-envy-free clustering always exist and can be computed efficiently.

Another Setting

[Li, M, Nikolov, S, 2023]

Model

  • Set of agents NNN partitioned into C=(C1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Ck‚Äã).
  • Cluster containing agent iii denoted by C(i)C(i)C(i).
  • Binary costs d:N√óN‚Üí{0,1}d:N\times N\to\{0,1\}d:N√óN‚Üí{0,1}

Theorem: There exists a balanced clustering (satisfying ‚à£C(i)‚à£=‚à£C(j)‚à£¬±1‚àÄi,j|C(i)|=|C(j)|\pm1\forall i,j‚à£C(i)‚à£=‚à£C(j)‚à£¬±1‚àÄi,j) s.t. for all i‚ààNi\in Ni‚ààN and j‚àà[k]j\in[k]j‚àà[k], ‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààC(i)d(i,i‚Ä≤)‚â§‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààCjd(i,i‚Ä≤)+O~(n/k)\sum_{i'\in C(i)}d(i,i')\le\sum_{i'\in C_j}d(i,i')+\tilde O(\sqrt{n/k})‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààC(i)‚Äãd(i,i‚Ä≤)‚â§‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààCj‚Äã‚Äãd(i,i‚Ä≤)+O~(n/k‚Äã).

  • If we divide by the size of the clusters, then the additive term becomes o(1)o(1)o(1).

Nash Social Welfare in ML

Multi-Armed Bandits

Â§öËáÇËµåÂçöÊú∫ÔºåÈÅóÊÜæÊúÄÂ∞èÂåñÁÆóÊ≥ï

kkk arms, Œº1,Œº2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,Œºk\mu_1,\mu_2,\cdots,\mu_kŒº1‚Äã,Œº2‚Äã,‚ãØ,Œºk‚Äã, Œº‚àó=arg‚Å°max‚Å°j‚àà[k]Œºj\mu^*=\arg\max_{j\in[k]}\mu_jŒº‚àó=argmaxj‚àà[k]‚ÄãŒºj‚Äã.

Exploration vs Exploitation

Regret RT=TŒº‚àó‚àí‚àët=1TŒº(t)R_T=T_{\mu^*}-\sum_{t=1}^T\mu(t)RT‚Äã=TŒº‚àó‚Äã‚àí‚àët=1T‚ÄãŒº(t)

Multi-Agent Multi-Armed Bandits

[Hossain, M, S, 2021]

Agents NNN

Each arm j‚àà[k]j\in[k]j‚àà[k] for each agent i‚ààNi\in Ni‚ààN have different data distribution Œºij\mu_{ij}Œºij‚Äã.

For each agent Œºi‚àó=arg‚Å°max‚Å°j‚àà[k]Œºij\mu_i^*=\arg\max_{j\in[k]}\mu_{ij}Œºi‚àó‚Äã=argmaxj‚àà[k]‚ÄãŒºij‚Äã.

‚ùìWhat is a fair policy?

Distribution p=[p1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,pk]p=[p_1,\cdots,p_k]p=[p1‚Äã,‚ãØ,pk‚Äã] gives expected reward ‚àëj=1kpj‚ãÖŒºij\sum_{j=1}^kp_j\cdot\mu_{ij}‚àëj=1k‚Äãpj‚Äã‚ãÖŒºij‚Äã to agent iii

Maximizing welfare functions

  1. Utilitarian welfare ‚àëi=1n‚àëj=1kpj‚ãÖŒºij\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^kp_j\cdot\mu_{ij}‚àëi=1n‚Äã‚àëj=1k‚Äãpj‚Äã‚ãÖŒºij‚Äã
  2. Egalitarian welfare min‚Å°i‚ààN‚àëj=1kpj‚ãÖŒºij\min_{i\in N}\sum_{j=1}^kp_j\cdot\mu_{ij}mini‚ààN‚Äã‚àëj=1k‚Äãpj‚Äã‚ãÖŒºij‚Äã
  3. Nash welfare ‚àèi=1n‚àëj=1kpj‚ãÖŒºij\prod_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^kp_j\cdot\mu_{ij}‚àèi=1n‚Äã‚àëj=1k‚Äãpj‚Äã‚ãÖŒºij‚Äã

Regret: RT=NSW(p‚àó,Œº)‚àí‚àët=1TNSW(p(t),Œº)R_T=NSW(p^*,\mu)-\sum_{t=1}^TNSW(p(t),\mu)RT‚Äã=NSW(p‚àó,Œº)‚àí‚àët=1T‚ÄãNSW(p(t),Œº)

ü§îTheorem: A variation of UCB achieves the optimal Œò(T)\Theta(\sqrt T)Œò(T‚Äã) regret.

Fair Exploration

[Barman, Khan, Maiti, Sawarni, 2023]

Agent ttt arrives at time ttt

We chose distribution PtP_tPt‚Äã, which gives the agent utility Ej‚àºPt[Œºj]E_{j\sim P_t}[\mu_j]Ej‚àºPt‚Äã‚Äã[Œºj‚Äã]

Regret: RT=Œº‚àó‚àí(‚àèt=1TEj‚àºPt[Œºj])1/TR_T=\mu^*-(\prod_{t=1}^TE_{j\sim P_t}[\mu_j])^{1/T}RT‚Äã=Œº‚àó‚àí(‚àèt=1T‚ÄãEj‚àºPt‚Äã‚Äã[Œºj‚Äã])1/T

Theorem: A variation of UCB achieves near-optimal regret in terms of TTT.

[Baek, Farias, 2021]

Agent ttt arrives at time ttt and belongs to group gtg_tgt‚Äã, where gt=gg_t=ggt‚Äã=g with probability pgp_gpg‚Äã

Policy: choose arm ata_tat‚Äã at time ttt

Regret for group g:uTg(œÄ)=‚àët‚àà[T]:gt=g(Œº‚àó‚àíŒºat)g:u_T^g(\pi)=\sum_{t\in[T]:g_t=g}(\mu^*-\mu_{a_t})g:uTg‚Äã(œÄ)=‚àët‚àà[T]:gt‚Äã=g‚Äã(Œº‚àó‚àíŒºat‚Äã‚Äã)

Utility to group g:ug(œÄ)=RTg(œÄ0)‚àíRTg(œÄ)g:u^g(\pi)=R_T^g(\pi^0)-R_T^g(\pi)g:ug(œÄ)=RTg‚Äã(œÄ0)‚àíRTg‚Äã(œÄ), where œÄ0\pi^0œÄ0 is the policy minimizing the overall regret

Nash social welfare: NSW(œÄ)=‚àègug(œÄ)NSW(\pi)=\prod_gu^g(\pi)NSW(œÄ)=‚àèg‚Äãug(œÄ)

Theorem: A version of UCB exactly optimizes NSW.

Core in ML

Federated Learning

[Chaudhury, Li, Kang, Li, Mehta, 2022]

FL: Choose fŒ∏:Rd‚ÜíRf_\theta:\mathbb R^d\to\mathbb RfŒ∏‚Äã:Rd‚ÜíR from F={fŒ∏:Œ∏‚ààP‚äÜRd}F=\{f_\theta:\theta\in P\subseteq\mathbb R^d\}F={fŒ∏‚Äã:Œ∏‚ààP‚äÜRd}

Utility of each agent: ui(Œ∏)=M‚àíE(x,y)‚àºDi[‚Ñì(fŒ∏(x),y)]u_i(\theta)=M-\mathbb E_{(x,y)\sim D_i}[\ell(f_\theta(x),y)]ui‚Äã(Œ∏)=M‚àíE(x,y)‚àºDi‚Äã‚Äã[‚Ñì(fŒ∏‚Äã(x),y)]

Goal: Choose Œ∏\thetaŒ∏ that is fair for all agents

Core: A parameter vector Œ∏‚ààP\theta\in PŒ∏‚ààP is in the core if for all Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP\theta'\in PŒ∏‚Ä≤‚ààP and S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN, it holds

ui(Œ∏)‚â•‚à£S‚à£‚à£N‚à£ui(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚àÄi‚ààS,u_i(\theta)\ge\frac{|S|}{|N|}u_i(\theta')\forall i\in S,ui‚Äã(Œ∏)‚â•‚à£N‚à£‚à£S‚à£‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚àÄi‚ààS,

with at least one strict inequality.

Pareto Optimality

Proportionality

ü§îTheorem: When the agents‚Äô utilities are continuous and the set of maximizer of any conical combination of the agents‚Äô utilities is convex, a parameter vector Œ∏‚ààP\theta\in PŒ∏‚ààP in the core always exists.

ü§îTheorem: When the agents‚Äô utilities are concave, then the parameter vector Œ∏‚ààP\theta\in PŒ∏‚ààP that maximizes the NEW is in the core:

maximize¬†‚àèi‚ààNui(Œ∏)¬†subject¬†to¬†Œ∏‚ààPmaximize¬†‚àëi‚ààNlog‚Å°(ui(Œ∏))¬†subject¬†to¬†Œ∏‚ààP\text{maximize }\prod_{i\in N}u_i(\theta)\text{ subject to }\theta\in P\\\text{maximize }\sum_{i\in N}\log(u_i(\theta))\text{ subject to }\theta\in Pmaximize¬†i‚ààN‚àè‚Äãui‚Äã(Œ∏)¬†subject¬†to¬†Œ∏‚ààPmaximize¬†i‚ààN‚àë‚Äãlog(ui‚Äã(Œ∏))¬†subject¬†to¬†Œ∏‚ààP

Clustering

In ML

Goal: Analyze datasets to summarize their characteristics

Objects in the same group are similar

In Economics

Goal: Allocate a set of facilities that serve a set of agents. (e.g. hospital)

Centroid Clustering

Input

  • Set NNN of nnn data points
  • Set MMM of mmm feasible cluster centers
  • ‚àÄi,j‚ààN‚à™M\forall i,j\in N\cup M‚àÄi,j‚ààN‚à™M: we have d(i,j)d(i,j)d(i,j) which forms a Metric Space
    • d(i,i)=0‚àÄi‚ààN‚à™Md(i,i)=0\forall i\in N\cup Md(i,i)=0‚àÄi‚ààN‚à™M
    • d(i,j)=d(j,i)‚àÄi,j‚ààN‚à™Md(i,j)=d(j,i)\forall i,j\in N\cup Md(i,j)=d(j,i)‚àÄi,j‚ààN‚à™M
    • d(i,j)‚â§d(i,k)+d(k,j)‚àÄi,j,k‚ààN‚à™Md(i,j)\le d(i,k)+d(k,j)\forall i,j,k\in N\cup Md(i,j)‚â§d(i,k)+d(k,j)‚àÄi,j,k‚ààN‚à™M

Output

  • A set C‚äÜMC\subseteq MC‚äÜM of kkk centers
  • Each data points is assigned to its closest cluster center C(i)=arg‚Å°min‚Å°c‚ààCd(i,c)C(i)=\arg\min_{c\in C}d(i,c)C(i)=argminc‚ààC‚Äãd(i,c)

Some Objective Functions

kkk-median: minimizes the sum of the distances

kkk-means: minimizes the sum of the square of the distances

kkk-center: minimizes the maximum distance

Fairness in Clustering

[Chen, Fain, Lyu, Munagala, 2019]

Fair clustering through proportional entitlement

  • Every group of n/kn/kn/k agents deserves its own cluster center

Definition in Committee Selection: WWW is the core if

  • For all S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN and T‚äÜMT\subseteq MT‚äÜM

  • If ‚à£S‚à£‚â•‚à£T‚à£‚ãÖn/k|S|\ge|T|\cdot n/k‚à£S‚à£‚â•‚à£T‚à£‚ãÖn/k, then ‚à£Ai‚à©W‚à£‚â•‚à£Ai‚à©T‚à£|A_i\cap W|\ge|A_i\cap T|‚à£Ai‚Äã‚à©W‚à£‚â•‚à£Ai‚Äã‚à©T‚à£ for some i‚ààSi\in Si‚ààS

    ‚ÄúIf a group can afford TTT, then TTT should not be a strict Pareto improvement for the group‚Äù

Definition in Clustering: CCC is in the core if

  • For all S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN and y‚äÜMy\subseteq My‚äÜM

  • If ‚à£S‚à£‚â•n/k|S|\ge n/k‚à£S‚à£‚â•n/k, then d(i,C(i))‚â§d(i,y)d(i,C(i))\le d(i,y)d(i,C(i))‚â§d(i,y) for some i‚ààSi\in Si‚ààS

    ‚ÄúIf a group can afford a center yyy, then yyy should not be a strict Pareto improvement for the group‚Äù

Core in Centroid Clustering

[Chen, Fain, Lyu, Munagala, 2019]

A clustering solution in the core does not always exist

Approximation core

Œ±\alphaŒ±-core: A solution CCC is in the Œ±\alphaŒ±-core with Œ±‚â•1\alpha\ge1Œ±‚â•1 if there is no group of points S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN with ‚à£S‚à£‚â•n/k|S|\ge n/k‚à£S‚à£‚â•n/k and y‚ààMy\in My‚ààM s.t.

‚àÄi‚ààS,Œ±‚ãÖd(i,y)<d(i,C(i))\forall i\in S,\alpha\cdot d(i,y)\lt d(i,C(i))‚àÄi‚ààS,Œ±‚ãÖd(i,y)<d(i,C(i))

ü§îTheorem. There exists an algorithm Greedy Capture that returns a clustering solution in the (1+2)(1+\sqrt2)(1+2‚Äã)-core under any metric space. For arbitrary metric spaces and Œ±<2\alpha\lt 2Œ±<2, a clustering solution in the Œ±\alphaŒ±-core is not guaranteed to exist.

ü§îTheorem.

  • For L2L_2L2‚Äã, Greedy Capture returns a solution in the 222-core
  • For L1L_1L1‚Äã and L‚àûL_\inftyL‚àû‚Äã, GC does not always return a (<1+2)(\lt1+\sqrt2)(<1+2‚Äã)-core
  • For L2L_2L2‚Äã and Œ±<1.154\alpha<1.154Œ±<1.154, a clustering solution in the Œ±\alphaŒ±-core is not guaranteed to exist
  • For L1L_1L1‚Äã and L‚àûL_\inftyL‚àû‚Äã, and Œ±<1.4\alpha\lt1.4Œ±<1.4, a clustering solution in the Œ±\alphaŒ±-core is not guaranteed to exist

Core in Non-Centroid Clustering

Non-Centroid Clustering

  • Partition the individuals into kkk clusters
  • loss for each cluster: for S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN and i‚ààS,‚Ñìi(S)‚â•0i\in S,\ell_i(S)\ge0i‚ààS,‚Ñìi‚Äã(S)‚â•0.

Œ±\alphaŒ±-core: A solution CCC is in the Œ±\alphaŒ±-core with Œ±‚â•1\alpha\ge1Œ±‚â•1, if there is no group of points S‚äÜNS\subseteq NS‚äÜN with ‚à£S‚à£‚â•n/k|S|\ge n/k‚à£S‚à£‚â•n/k s.t.

‚àÄi‚ààS,‚Ñìi(S)<‚Ñìi(C(i))\forall i\in S,\ell_i(S)\lt\ell_i(C(i))‚àÄi‚ààS,‚Ñìi‚Äã(S)<‚Ñìi‚Äã(C(i))

Average loss: for each S‚äÜN,‚Ñìi(S)=1‚à£S‚à£‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààSd(i,i‚Ä≤)S\subseteq N,\ell_i(S)=\frac{1}{|S|}\sum_{i'\in S}d(i,i')S‚äÜN,‚Ñìi‚Äã(S)=‚à£S‚à£1‚Äã‚àëi‚Ä≤‚ààS‚Äãd(i,i‚Ä≤)

ü§îTheorem

  • Greedy Capture returns a clustering solution in the (n/k)(n/k)(n/k)-core under any metric space
  • For arbitrary metric space and Œ±<1.366\alpha\lt1.366Œ±<1.366, a clustering solution in the Œ±\alphaŒ±-core is not guaranteed to exist

Open question: Does a clustering solution in the O(1)O(1)O(1)-core always exist?

Folk/Mennesker/Personer Ëæ®Êûê

  • Mennesker

    • ÈÄöÂ∏∏Êåá‰∏ÄÁæ§ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑ‰∫∫ÔºåÈÄöÂ∏∏Âú®‰ª£ËØçÊàñÂΩ¢ÂÆπËØç‰πãÂêéÔºàmange, en del, de fleste, ingen, nogle ‚Ä¶Ôºâ

entry.title: ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂíåËÆ°ÁÆóÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ 7 Bounded Depth Boolean Circuits
entry.content:
What if Boolean circuits has bounded depth?

Depth of Boolean circuit: the length of a longest path from an input gate to an output gate.

It‚Äôs a model of parallel computation where depth corresponds to parallel time.

Parallel model of random access machine PRAM ÁóõËã¶ÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÂá†‰ΩïËØæÁöÑÂõûÂøÜ

üìñDefinition of SIZE‚àíDEPTHSIZE-DEPTHSIZE‚àíDEPTH. Let S:N‚ÜíNS:\mathbb N\to\mathbb NS:N‚ÜíN and d:N‚ÜíNd:\mathbb N\to\mathbb Nd:N‚ÜíN. SIZE‚àíDEPTH(S(n),d(n))SIZE-DEPTH(S(n),d(n))SIZE‚àíDEPTH(S(n),d(n)) is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) and depth O(d(n))O(d(n))O(d(n)).

üìñDefinition of NCiNC^iNCi. For i‚â•0i\ge0i‚â•0, define NCi=SIZE‚àíDEPTH(nO(1),log‚Å°i(n))NC^i=SIZE-DEPTH(n^{O(1)},\log^i(n))NCi=SIZE‚àíDEPTH(nO(1),logi(n)), and further define NC=‚à™i‚â•1NCiNC=\cup_{i\ge1}NC^iNC=‚à™i‚â•1‚ÄãNCi.

These circuit classes is restrict to polynomial size and poly-logarithmic depth.

By definition, NC‚äÜP/polyNC\subseteq P/polyNC‚äÜP/poly, hence UL‚àíNC‚äÜPU_L-NC\subseteq PUL‚Äã‚àíNC‚äÜP.

‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÂë¢ÔºüÂõûÈ°æÂÆö‰πâ P/poly=‚ãÉk>0SIZE(nk)P/poly=\bigcup_{k\gt0}SIZE(n^k)P/poly=‚ãÉk>0‚ÄãSIZE(nk)ÔºåÂèëÁé∞ÂÆÉÁöÑÂ§ö‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê∑±Â∫¶ÁöÑÈôêÂà∂„ÄÇ

In fact P‚äÜÃ∏NCP\not\subseteq NCPÓÄ†‚äÜNC is expected to hold. This means not all languages in PPP can benefit greatly from parallelism.

General Boolean Circuits

Consider Boolean circuits that allows arbitrary fanin gate and more general functions than AND,OR,NOTAND, OR, NOTAND,OR,NOT.

General definition of Boolean circuit. A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  • An underlying directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) (multiple arcs is allowed)
  • A labeling ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì of the nodes of VVV.
  • A linear ordering on the arcs AAA of VVV.
  • A choice of mmm output gates o1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,om‚ààVo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1‚Äã,‚ãØ,om‚Äã‚ààV

The size of CCC is the number of wires. The labelling function ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì should satisfy the following for all gates ggg:

  • If the fanin of ggg is 000, then ‚Ñì(g)‚àà{0,1,x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn,x1‚Äæ,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn‚Äæ}\ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n}\}‚Ñì(g)‚àà{0,1,x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã,x1‚Äã‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã‚Äã}.
  • If the fanin of ggg is k‚â•1k\ge1k‚â•1, then ‚Ñì(g)=fg\ell(g)=f_g‚Ñì(g)=fg‚Äã where fg:{0,1}k‚Üí{0,1}f_g:\{0,1\}^k\to\{0,1\}fg‚Äã:{0,1}k‚Üí{0,1} is an kkk-ary Boolean function.

CCC compute a Boolean function f:{0,1}n‚Üí{0,1}mf:\{0,1\}^n\to\{0,1\}^mf:{0,1}n‚Üí{0,1}m in a natural way.

Boolean functions with k-ary

AND(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=z_1\and\cdots\and z_k\\OR(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=z_1\or\cdots\or z_k\\MOD_m(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\not\equiv0\mod m\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\equiv0\mod m\end{cases}

MOD2MOD_2MOD2‚Äã is the same as the xor-sum.

The major voting function MAJMAJMAJ:

MAJ(z1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,zk)={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1kzi‚â•k20¬†if¬†‚àëi=1kzi<k2MAJ(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\ge\frac{k}{2}\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\lt\frac{k}{2}\end{cases}MAJ(z1‚Äã,‚ãØ,zk‚Äã)={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1k‚Äãzi‚Äã‚â•2k‚Äã0¬†if¬†‚àëi=1k‚Äãzi‚Äã<2k‚Äã‚Äã

Let w=(w1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,wk)‚ààRkw=(w_1,\cdots,w_k)\in\mathbb R^kw=(w1‚Äã,‚ãØ,wk‚Äã)‚ààRk be weights and t‚ààRt\in\mathbb Rt‚ààR be a threshold. Then THRw,tTHR_{w,t}THRw,t‚Äã is defined:

THRw,t(z1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,zk)={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1kwizi‚â•t0¬†if¬†‚àëi=1kwizi<tTHR_{w,t}(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kw_iz_i\ge t\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kw_iz_i\lt t\end{cases}THRw,t‚Äã(z1‚Äã,‚ãØ,zk‚Äã)={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1k‚Äãwi‚Äãzi‚Äã‚â•t0¬†if¬†‚àëi=1k‚Äãwi‚Äãzi‚Äã<t‚Äã

When all weights is 111,

Tt(z1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,zk)={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1kzi‚â•t0¬†if¬†‚àëi=1kzi<tT_t(z_1,\cdots,z_k)=\begin{cases}1\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\ge t\\0\ if\ \sum_{i=1}^kz_i\lt t\end{cases}Tt‚Äã(z1‚Äã,‚ãØ,zk‚Äã)={1¬†if¬†‚àëi=1k‚Äãzi‚Äã‚â•t0¬†if¬†‚àëi=1k‚Äãzi‚Äã<t‚Äã

Several Circuit Classes

üìñDefinition of ACiAC^iACi. For i‚â•0i\ge0i‚â•0, ACiAC^iACi is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(log‚Å°in)O(\log^in)O(login) using unbounded fanin ANDANDAND and OROROR gates.

ACiAC^iACi is similar to NCiNC^iNCi.

ü§îProposition 5. Hierarchy relation between NCNCNC and ACACAC. NCi‚äÜACi‚äÜNCi+1NC^i\subseteq AC^i\subseteq NC^{i+1}NCi‚äÜACi‚äÜNCi+1 for all i‚â•0i\ge0i‚â•0.

For ACi‚äÜNCi+1AC^i\subseteq NC^{i+1}ACi‚äÜNCi+1: ANDANDAND and OROROR gates of fanin kkk can be replaced by a binary tree of depth ‚åàlog‚Å°2k‚åâ\lceil\log_2k\rceil‚åàlog2‚Äãk‚åâ of corresponding fanin 222 gates. Thus the depth increases by a factor O(log‚Å°n)O(\log n)O(logn).

üìñDefinition of AC0,ACC0AC^0,ACC^0AC0,ACC0. Let m>1m\gt1m>1. AC0[m]AC^0[m]AC0[m] is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(1)O(1)O(1) using unbounded fanin AND,OR,MODmAND,OR,MOD_mAND,OR,MODm‚Äã gates. Define ACC0=‚ãÉm>1AC0[m]ACC^0=\bigcup_{m\gt1}AC^0[m]ACC0=‚ãÉm>1‚ÄãAC0[m].

üìñDefinition of TC0TC^0TC0. TC0TC^0TC0 is the class of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits of polynomial size and depth O(1)O(1)O(1) using unbounded fanin MAJMAJMAJ gates only.

Logarithmic Space and Logarithmic Depth Circuits

log-space can be roughly the same as log-depth circuits.

üéØTheorem 38. UL‚àíNC1‚äÜLU_L-NC^1\subseteq LUL‚Äã‚àíNC1‚äÜL.

Circuit CCC with depth (log‚Å°n)(\log n)(logn) is computable by a O(log‚Å°n)O(\log n)O(logn) space Turing Machine.

üìñDefinition of Boolean product of matrices. A=(aij)‚àà{0,1}m√ór,B=(bij)‚àà{0,1}r√ónA=(a_{ij})\in\{0,1\}^{m\times r},B=(b_{ij})\in\{0,1\}^{r\times n}A=(aij‚Äã)‚àà{0,1}m√ór,B=(bij‚Äã)‚àà{0,1}r√ón. The Boolean product ABABAB is the m√ónm\times nm√ón Boolean matrix C=(cij)C=(c_{ij})C=(cij‚Äã) s.t.

c_{ij}=\bigvee_{k=1}^ra_{ik}\and a_{kj}.

A n√ónn\times nn√ón Boolean matrix corresponds to a directed graph. The transitive closure of the graph gives rise to the transitive closure of the matrix.

Functions and Reductions

Boolean circuit is fixed number of inputs, we consider output is also a bounded function of the length of input.

üìñDefinition of length-respecting. A function f:{0,1}‚àó‚Üí{0,1}‚àóf:\{0,1\}^*\to\{0,1\}^*f:{0,1}‚àó‚Üí{0,1}‚àó is length-respecting if for all x,y‚àà{0,1}‚àóx,y\in\{0,1\}^*x,y‚àà{0,1}‚àó, we have ‚à£x‚à£=‚à£y‚à£‚áí‚à£f(x)‚à£=‚à£f(y)‚à£|x|=|y|\Rarr|f(x)|=|f(y)|‚à£x‚à£=‚à£y‚à£‚áí‚à£f(x)‚à£=‚à£f(y)‚à£.

üìñDefinition of AC0AC^0AC0 Turing reduction. Let fff and ggg be length-respecting Boolean functions. We say fff reduces to ggg by an AC0AC^0AC0 Turing reduction if fff is computed by a family of Boolean functions of polynomial size and depth O(1)O(1)O(1) using unbounded fanin ANDANDAND and OROROR gates as well as gates computing any coordinate function of ggg.

ADDADDADD: given nnn-bit numbers xxx and yyy, output n+1n+1n+1-bit number zzz s.t. z=x+yz=x+yz=x+y.

We can to reduce the task to the task of add 222 numbers each of n+O(log‚Å°n)n+O(\log n)n+O(logn) bits. These may be added in depth O(log‚Å°n)O(\log n)O(logn) by converting AC0AC^0AC0 for ADDADDADD to a NC1NC^1NC1 circuit.

Given nnn-bit numbers xxx and yyy, we form the nnn numbers ziz^izi, each of 2n‚àí12n-12n‚àí1 bits by letting zi=xi2iyz^i=x_i2^iyzi=xi‚Äã2iy for 0‚â§i<n0\le i\lt n0‚â§i<n. Then the product is simply the sum of the numbers z0,‚ãØ‚Äâ,zn‚àí1z^0,\cdots,z^{n-1}z0,‚ãØ,zn‚àí1.

BCOUNTBCOUNTBCOUNT: given nnn-bit number xxx, output ‚åàlog‚Å°2n+1‚åâ\lceil\log_2^n+1\rceil‚åàlog2n‚Äã+1‚åâ-bit number zzz, the sum of each bit.

entry.title: ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂíåËÆ°ÁÆóÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ 6 Randomized Computation
entry.content:
What if Turing machine models have access to a source of randomness?

This would allow to compute more in same time/space, at the price of possibly not giving correct answer with small probability.

Current consensus: Randomization only gives

  • Polynomial saving in time
  • Constant factor saving in space

Because of hardness-based pseudo-random generator.

Exponential time: E=DTIME(2O(n))=UL‚àíSIZE(2O(n))E=DTIME(2^{O(n)})=U_L-SIZE(2^{O(n)})E=DTIME(2O(n))=UL‚Äã‚àíSIZE(2O(n)). (By corollary 2)

Recall that SIZE(2n/n)SIZE(2^n/n)SIZE(2n/n) includes every Boolean function on nnn variables, making non-uniform inclusion E‚äÜSIZE(2O(n))E\subseteq SIZE(2^{O(n)})E‚äÜSIZE(2O(n)).

Corresponding randomized complexity class BPPBPPBPP.

Theorem 33 (Impagliazzo and Wigderson). If there exists L‚ààEL\in EL‚ààE s.t. for every nnn and every Boolean circuit CCC computing LLL on input length nnn, the size of CCC must be 2Œ©(n)2^{\Omega(n)}2Œ©(n), then P=BPPP=BPPP=BPP.

Probabilistic Turing Machines

Give a probabilistic Turing machine an extra read-only and read-once tape which is pre-initialized with uniform and independent random bits. The tape head is allow to only stop or move forward.

Thus everything related to the Turing machines becomes a random variable.

Different kinds of Errors

Zero-sided error aka Las Vegas computation: Turing machine halt in a state ‚Äú?‚Äù with small probability and require correct answer otherwise.

One-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives.

Two-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives and false positives.

üìñDefinition 19. Let MMM be a probabilistic Turing machine and LLL a language.

  • MMM computes LLL with zero-sided error if for all xxx we have Pr‚Å°[M(x)=?]‚â§14\Pr[M(x)=?]\le\frac{1}{4}Pr[M(x)=?]‚â§41‚Äã, that M(x)‚àà{yes,?}M(x)\in\{yes,?\}M(x)‚àà{yes,?} when x‚ààLx\in Lx‚ààL, and that M(x)‚àà{no,?}M(x)\in\{no,?\}M(x)‚àà{no,?} when x‚ààÃ∏Lx\not\in LxÓÄ†‚ààL.
  • MMM computes LLL with one-sided error if for all x‚ààLx\in Lx‚ààL we have Pr‚Å°[M(x)=yes]‚â•34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]‚â•43‚Äã and for all x‚ààÃ∏Lx\not\in LxÓÄ†‚ààL we have M(x)=noM(x)=noM(x)=no.
  • MMM computes LLL with two-sided error if for all x‚ààLx\in Lx‚ààL we have Pr‚Å°[M(x)=yes]‚â•34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]‚â•43‚Äã and for all x‚ààÃ∏Lx\not\in LxÓÄ†‚ààL we have Pr‚Å°[M(x)=no]‚â•34\Pr[M(x)=no]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=no]‚â•43‚Äã.

üìñDefinition 20. Let T:N‚ÜíNT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:N‚ÜíN and S:N‚ÜíNS:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NS:N‚ÜíN be functions with T(n)‚â•nT(n)\ge nT(n)‚â•n.

  • Then ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n)), RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n)) and BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded probabilistic Turing machine with zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.
  • ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n)), RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n)) and BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded probabilistic Turing machine that always halt having zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.

For space bounded randomized classes, we assume that the Turing machine always halts! Because otherwise these three classes would end up containing NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))!

Define log-space/polynomial time bounded classes:

ZPL=ZPSPACE(log‚Å°n)RP=RSPACE(log‚Å°n)BPL=BPSPACE(log‚Å°n)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))ZPL=ZPSPACE(\log n)\\RP=RSPACE(\log n)\\BPL=BPSPACE(\log n)\\ZPP=ZPTIME(n^{O(1)})\\RP=RTIME(n^{O(1)})\\BPP=BPTIME(n^{O(1)})ZPL=ZPSPACE(logn)RP=RSPACE(logn)BPL=BPSPACE(logn)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))

Trivially, L‚äÜZPL‚äÜRL‚äÜBPLL\subseteq ZPL\subseteq RL\subseteq BPLL‚äÜZPL‚äÜRL‚äÜBPL; P‚äÜZPP‚äÜRP‚äÜBPPP\subseteq ZPP\subseteq RP\subseteq BPPP‚äÜZPP‚äÜRP‚äÜBPP.

It‚Äôs also easy to see that RL‚äÜNLRL\subseteq NLRL‚äÜNL and RP‚äÜNPRP\subseteq NPRP‚äÜNP.

Simple upper bound for BPPBPPBPP (not tight): similar to theorem 10, BPP‚äÜPSPACEBPP\subseteq PSPACEBPP‚äÜPSPACE.

For BPLBPLBPL, BPL‚äÜDSPACE(log‚Å°3/2n)BPL\subseteq DSPACE(\log^{3/2}n)BPL‚äÜDSPACE(log3/2n).

Success Amplification

Error probability of 1/41/41/4 is large, but we can reduce it by independently running multiple times.

For zero-sided error, we won‚Äôt stop until we get non-unknown answer.

For one-sided error, if some trial accepts, we accept. otherwise we reject.

For two-sided error, we decided the answer by the majority of trials.

ü§îLemma 3. Let X1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1‚Äã,‚ãØ,Xk‚Äã be independent Boolean variables s.t. Pr‚Å°[Xi=1]‚â•œµ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\epsilonPr[Xi‚Äã=1]‚â•œµ. Then

Pr‚Å°[‚àÄi:Xi=0]<exp‚Å°(‚àíkœµ)\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]\lt\exp(-k\epsilon)Pr[‚àÄi:Xi‚Äã=0]<exp(‚àíkœµ)

By independence,

Pr‚Å°[‚àÄi:Xi=0]=‚àèiPr‚Å°[Xi=0]<(1‚àíœµ)k‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àíkœµ).\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]=\prod_i\Pr[X_i=0]\lt(1-\epsilon)^k\le\exp(-k\epsilon).Pr[‚àÄi:Xi‚Äã=0]=i‚àè‚ÄãPr[Xi‚Äã=0]<(1‚àíœµ)k‚â§exp(‚àíkœµ).

(by 1+x‚â§exp‚Å°(x)1+x\le\exp(x)1+x‚â§exp(x))

Apply this to zero-sided and one-sided errors:

  • Define XiX_iXi‚Äã to indicate whether trial iii gives the correct output.
  • Instead of having error probability 1/41/41/4, we actually assume that error probability for once is less than 1‚àí1p(n)1-\frac{1}{p(n)}1‚àíp(n)1‚Äã and still achieve error probability exp‚Å°(‚àíq(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(‚àíq(n)) for all by running k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n) trials, which is polynomial number.

For two-sided error:

ü§îLemma 4 (Chernoff-Hoeffding Bound). Let XXX be the sum of kkk independent Boolean random variables. Assume ŒºL‚â§E[X]‚â§ŒºH\mu_L\le\mathbb E[X]\le\mu_HŒºL‚Äã‚â§E[X]‚â§ŒºH‚Äã, t>0t>0t>0. Then

Pr‚Å°[X<ŒºL‚àít]‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àí2t2/k),Pr‚Å°[X>ŒºH+t]‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àí2t2/k).\Pr[X<\mu_L-t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k),\\\Pr[X>\mu_H+t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k).Pr[X<ŒºL‚Äã‚àít]‚â§exp(‚àí2t2/k),Pr[X>ŒºH‚Äã+t]‚â§exp(‚àí2t2/k).

We define the random indicator XiX_iXi‚Äã to indicate whether trial iii gave correct output. We assume that Pr‚Å°[Xi=1]‚â•12+œµ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\frac{1}{2}+\epsilonPr[Xi‚Äã=1]‚â•21‚Äã+œµ and kkk is odd. Let X=‚àëi=1kXiX=\sum_{i=1}^kX_iX=‚àëi=1k‚ÄãXi‚Äã, we have E[X]‚â•k2+kœµ\mathbb E[X]\ge\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonE[X]‚â•2k‚Äã+kœµ. Applying Chernoff-Hoeffding bound, we have

Pr‚Å°[X<k2]=Pr‚Å°[X<ŒºL‚àíkœµ]‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àí2(kœµ)2/k)=exp‚Å°(‚àí2kœµ2)\Pr[X<\frac{k}{2}]=\Pr[X<\mu_L-k\epsilon]\le\exp(-2(k\epsilon)^2/k)\\=\exp(-2k\epsilon^2)Pr[X<2k‚Äã]=Pr[X<ŒºL‚Äã‚àíkœµ]‚â§exp(‚àí2(kœµ)2/k)=exp(‚àí2kœµ2)

using ŒºL=k2+kœµ\mu_L=\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonŒºL‚Äã=2k‚Äã+kœµ. Instead of have error probability 1/41/41/4, we assume error probability for once just less than 1/2‚àí1/p(n)1/2-1/p(n)1/2‚àí1/p(n) and achieve error probability exp‚Å°(‚àíq(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(‚àíq(n)) by running k=p(n)2q(n)2k=\frac{p(n)^2q(n)}{2}k=2p(n)2q(n)‚Äã independent trials.

These analysis applies to both polynomial-time bounded and log-space bounded randomized complexity classes.

Polynomial Identity Testing

Don‚Äôt know:

  1. Whether randomized classes have complete problem;
  2. Any hierarchy results for randomized classes.

PIT

Polynomial Identity Testing (PIT): Testing whether a polynomial is identically zero.

PIT problem is efficiently solvable in randomized polynomial time but not known to be solvable deterministically in polynomial time.

üìñDefinition 21 (Arithmetic circuit). An arithmetic circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  1. A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) where the in-degree of every node is either 000 or 222.
  2. A labeling ‚Ñì\ell‚Ñì for the nodes VVV.
  3. A choice of mmm outputs gates o1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,om‚ààVo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1‚Äã,‚ãØ,om‚Äã‚ààV.

Nodes VVV corresponds to gates, edges AAA corresponds to wires. Nodes of in-degree 000 are input gates. The labeling function satisfies ‚àÄ\forall‚àÄ gates ggg:

  1. If fanin of ggg is 000, ‚Ñì(g)‚àà{1,x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn}\ell(g)\in\{1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}‚Ñì(g)‚àà{1,x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã}.
  2. If fanin of ggg is 222, ‚Ñì(g)‚àà{+,√ó,‚àí}\ell(g)\in\{+,\times,-\}‚Ñì(g)‚àà{+,√ó,‚àí}.

ÊïÖÊÑè‰∏çËØ¥‰∫∫ËØù‚Ä¶‚Ä¶Â∞±ÊòØÊääÂ§öÈ°πÂºèÂàÜËß£ÊàêÂ§öÂ±Ç‰∫åÂÖÉËøêÁÆó„ÄÇ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§öÈ°πÂºèÂ∞±Áõ∏ÂΩì‰∫éÂè™Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËæìÂá∫Âè£ÁöÑÁÆóÊúØÁîµË∑Ø„ÄÇ

Such an arithmetic circuit compute a polynomial p‚ààR[x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn]p\in R[x_1,\cdots,x_n]p‚ààR[x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã] for any Abelian ring RRR. ÈòøË¥ùÂ∞îÁéØ

Usually we consider arithmetic circuits w.r.t. ring.

AFIT

aka Arithmetic formula identity testing

A variant of PIT: input polynomial is given by an arithmetic formula.

Instance: Arithmetic formula computing the polynomial P(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)‚ààZ[x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã)‚ààZ[x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã].

Question: Is P(x)‚â°0P(x)\equiv0P(x)‚â°0?

A simple randomized algorithm: simply choose number a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an‚àà{1,2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,4m}a_1,\cdots,a_n\in\{1,2,\cdots,4m\}a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã‚àà{1,2,‚ãØ,4m} independently and uniformly at random, where mmm is the size of the given formula, evaluate P(a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an)P(a_1,\cdots, a_n)P(a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã) and answer accordingly.

Using Schwartz-Zippel lemma to analyze error probability.

ü§îLemma 5 (Schwartz-Zippel lemma). Let F\mathbb FF be a field, let P(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)‚ààF[x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn]P(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb F[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã)‚ààF[x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã] be a non-zero polynomial of total degree at most ddd. Let S‚äÜFS\subseteq\mathbb FS‚äÜF, and pick a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an‚ààSa_1,\cdots, a_n\in Sa1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã‚ààS independently and uniformly at random. Then

Pr‚Å°[P(a1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,an)=0]‚â§d‚à£S‚à£.\Pr[P(a_1,\cdots,a_n)=0]\le\frac{d}{|S|}.Pr[P(a1‚Äã,‚ãØ,an‚Äã)=0]‚â§‚à£S‚à£d‚Äã.

Proof by induction on nnn.

So the error probability is decided by mmm, at most 1/41/41/4.

üéØTheorem 45. AFIT‚ààcoRPAFIT\in coRPAFIT‚ààcoRP.

Ê≤°Â§™ÊáÇËøô‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜ

Sample from 1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,m1,\cdots,m1,‚ãØ,m is equivalent to sample kkk times from 1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,2‚åàlog‚Å°2m‚åâ1,\cdots,2^{\lceil\log_2m\rceil}1,‚ãØ,2‚åàlog2‚Äãm‚åâ. k=œâ(log‚Å°n)k=\omega(\log n)k=œâ(logn).

ACIT

aka arithmetic circuit identity testing

Instance: Arithmetic circuit computing the polynomial P(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)‚ààZ[x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã)‚ààZ[x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã].

Question: Is P(x)‚â°0P(x)\equiv0P(x)‚â°0?

Circuit of size mmm has at most mmm multiplication gates. The degree of the polynomial computed is at most 2m2^m2m. The same approach as in arithmetic formula calls for draw random number from 1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,2m+21,\cdots,2^{m+2}1,‚ãØ,2m+2. (exponential!)

To remedy this, we switch to modular arithmetic with randomly chosen prime modulus. Use prime number theorem to analyze error probability.

Let œÄ(x)\pi(x)œÄ(x) be the number of prime number less than xxx. By prime number theory,

œÄ(x)‚àºxln‚Å°x.\pi(x)\sim\frac{x}{\ln x}.œÄ(x)‚àºlnxx‚Äã.

ü§îLemma 6. For all m>1m>1m>1, we have œÄ(2m)‚â•2mm\pi(2^m)\ge\frac{2^m}{m}œÄ(2m)‚â•m2m‚Äã.

ü§îüéØTheorem 35. ACIT‚ààcoRPACIT\in coRPACIT‚ààcoRP.

Det kan jeg ikke forst√•r

An Alternative Characterization of Time Bounded Classes

We have alternative characterization of BPPBPPBPP. Also there are similar alternatives of ZPPZPPZPP and RPRPRP.

Proposition 4. Let LLL be a language. Then L‚ààBPPL\in BPPL‚ààBPP iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L‚Ä≤‚ààPL'\in PL‚Ä≤‚ààP s.t. ‚àÄx\forall x‚àÄx:

x‚ààL‚áíPr‚Å°y‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤]‚â•34x‚ààÃ∏L‚áíPr‚Å°y‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààÃ∏L‚Ä≤]‚â•34x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\not\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}x‚ààL‚áíy‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)Pr‚Äã[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤]‚â•43‚ÄãxÓÄ†‚ààL‚áíy‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)Pr‚Äã[‚ü®x,y‚ü©ÓÄ†‚ààL‚Ä≤]‚â•43‚Äã

We say that the randomized computation uses q(‚à£x‚à£)q(|x|)q(‚à£x‚à£) random bits.

Using success amplification a randomized algorithm using RRR random bits and having error probability less than 1/41/41/4 can be transformed to a randomized algorithm using kRkRkR random bits and having error probability less than exp‚Å°(‚àík/8)\exp(-k/8)exp(‚àík/8) by running kkk trials and taking the majority vote.

Randomized Computation and the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

By definition, RP‚äÜNPRP\subseteq NPRP‚äÜNP.

But we don‚Äôt know whether BPP‚äÜNPBPP\subseteq NPBPP‚äÜNP or NP‚äÜBPPNP\subseteq BPPNP‚äÜBPP.

We just guess: BPP=PBPP=PBPP=P thus BPP‚äÜNPBPP\subseteq NPBPP‚äÜNP.

But we can prove that BPPBPPBPP is contained in the second level of polynomial-time hierarchy.

üéØTheorem 36. BPP‚äÜŒ£2P‚à©Œ†2PBPP\subseteq \Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PBPP‚äÜŒ£2P‚Äã‚à©Œ†2P‚Äã.

Prove that BPP‚äÜŒ£2PBPP\subseteq\Sigma_2^PBPP‚äÜŒ£2P‚Äã. From this also we get BPP‚äÜŒ†2PBPP\subseteq\Pi_2^PBPP‚äÜŒ†2P‚Äã.

  • Let L‚ààBPPL\in BPPL‚ààBPP. We have a polynomial q(n)q(n)q(n) and a language L‚Ä≤‚ààPL'\in PL‚Ä≤‚ààP s.t. for all xxx we have

    x‚ààL‚áíPr‚Å°y‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤]‚â•1‚àí12q(‚à£x‚à£),x‚ààÃ∏L‚áíPr‚Å°y‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤]<1‚àí12q(‚à£x‚à£).x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge1-\frac{1}{2q(|x|)},\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']<1-\frac{1}{2q(|x|)}.x‚ààL‚áíy‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)Pr‚Äã[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤]‚â•1‚àí2q(‚à£x‚à£)1‚Äã,xÓÄ†‚ààL‚áíy‚àà{0,1}q(‚à£x‚à£)Pr‚Äã[‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤]<1‚àí2q(‚à£x‚à£)1‚Äã.

  • Let m=q(‚à£x‚à£)m=q(|x|)m=q(‚à£x‚à£). For given xxx, we define Sx={y‚àà{0,1}m‚à£‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤}S_x=\{y\in\{0,1\}^m|\langle x,y\rangle\in L'\}Sx‚Äã={y‚àà{0,1}m‚à£‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤}. Thus, for all xxx we have

    x‚ààL‚áí‚à£Sx‚à£‚â•(1‚àí12m)2m,x‚ààÃ∏L‚áí‚à£Sx‚à£<12m2m.x\in L\Rarr|S_x|\ge(1-\frac{1}{2m})2^m,\\x\not\in L\Rarr|S_x|<\frac{1}{2m}2^m.x‚ààL‚áí‚à£Sx‚Äã‚à£‚â•(1‚àí2m1‚Äã)2m,xÓÄ†‚ààL‚áí‚à£Sx‚Äã‚à£<2m1‚Äã2m.

    Claim that x‚ààLx\in Lx‚ààL iff

    ‚àÉu1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,um‚àà{0,1}m‚àÄr‚àà{0,1}m:‚ãÅi=1m‚ü®x,ui‚äïr‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤,\exist u_1,\cdots, u_m\in\{0,1\}^m\forall r\in\{0,1\}^m:\\\bigvee_{i=1}^m\langle x,u_i\oplus r\rangle\in L',‚àÉu1‚Äã,‚ãØ,um‚Äã‚àà{0,1}m‚àÄr‚àà{0,1}m:i=1‚ãÅm‚Äã‚ü®x,ui‚Äã‚äïr‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤,

    where ui‚äïru_i\oplus rui‚Äã‚äïr denote the coordinate-wise exclusive-or. ‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØÂùêÊ†áÊàñËøêÁÆóÔºü

  • This shows that L‚ààŒ£2PL\in\Sigma_2^PL‚ààŒ£2P‚Äã since this can be done in polynomial time.

It remains to prove the predicate is equivalent to ‚ãÉi=1mui‚äïSx={0,1}m\bigcup_{i=1}^mu_i\oplus S_x=\{0,1\}^m‚ãÉi=1m‚Äãui‚Äã‚äïSx‚Äã={0,1}m.

Randomized Computation and Boolean Circuits

Everything that can be computed in polynomial-time by randomized algorithm can also be computed using Boolean circuits.

üéØTheorem 37. (Adleman‚Äôs Theorem). BPP‚äÜP/polyBPP\subseteq P/polyBPP‚äÜP/poly.

Ë¥™ÂøÉ„ÄÇ‰∏ÄÊÆµ‰∏ÄÊÆµÂú∞ÊâæÔºåÂè™Ë¶ÅÂèëÁé∞ÊúâÂá†‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†Áõ∏‰πòÁ≠â‰∫é xxxÔºåÂ∞±Á´ãÈ©¨ÂàáÂºÄ„ÄÇÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂÆûÁé∞ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî® C++ STL ÈáåÈ´òÊïàÁöÑ set Êù•Â≠òÂÇ®ÊâÄÊúâ xxx Èô§‰ª•‰∏Ä‰∫õÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÂïÜÔºå‰∏ÄÊó¶Êñ∞Êâ´ÊèèÁöÑÂÄºÂåπÈÖç‰∏ä‰∫ÜÔºåÂ∞±Á´ãÂàªÂàáÂºÄ„ÄÇ

G. Ultra-Meow

entry.summary:
Êú¨Ê¨°ÊØîËµõ ÈìæÊé•

Áé∞Âú®ÁöÑÊ∞¥Âπ≥Âè™ËÉΩÁ¢∞Á¢∞ Div 3

entry.title: ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂíåËÆ°ÁÆóÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ 5 The Polynomoial-Time Hierarchy
entry.content:
Idea: arithmetic hierarchy from recursion theory.

Halting problem HALTHALTHALT is a recursive enumerable language that is undecidable.

The polynomial-time hierarchy considers polynomial time and SATSATSAT instead of HALTHALTHALT.

Oracle Turing Machines

An oracle Turing machine M?M^?M? is equipped with an additional tape, the query tape, and has three new special states qask,qyes,qnoq_{ask},q_{yes},q_{no}qask‚Äã,qyes‚Äã,qno‚Äã. The query tape is a write-only tape.

The operation of M?M^?M? is defined relative to an oracle language AAA.

Denote M?M^?M? together with oracle language AAA by MAM^AMA.

Whenever MAM^AMA enters the state qaskq_{ask}qask‚Äã:

  • Let zzz be the string of symbols written to the query tape. The query tape is reinitialized to a black tape.
  • If z‚ààAz\in Az‚ààA, computation resumes in the state qyesq_{yes}qyes‚Äã.
  • If z‚ààÃ∏Az\not\in AzÓÄ†‚ààA, computation resumes in the state qnoq_{no}qno‚Äã.

Define timeMA(x)time_{M^A}(x)timeMA‚Äã(x) and spaceMA(x)space_{M^A}(x)spaceMA‚Äã(x) for an oracle Turing machine with an oracle language AAA to be the number of computation steps and number of cells of work tape used during computation on input xxx. The same way we define time-bounded and space-bounded oracle Turing machines.

Then we need to define oracle versions of complexity classes. Straightforward to define time-bounded complexity classes, but be careful to define space-bounded complexity classes.

DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^A(T(n)),DSPACE^A(S(n)),NTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n)).

‚ùóProblem for non-deterministic space-bounded oracle Turing machine: it may write very long strings to the oracle tape.

Solution: Requiring the oracle Turing machine to behave deterministically in the time between writing the first symbol to the oracle tape and making the oracle query. (deterministic oracle access)

Thus we define NSPACEA(S(n))NSPACE^A(S(n))NSPACEA(S(n)) as the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded non-deterministic oracle Turing machine with deterministic oracle access to oracle AAA.

The definition can be extended to other complexity classes.

PAP^APA and NPANP^ANPA for any oracle language AAA.

The oracle may be chosen from some class of languages. Let C\mathcal CC be a class of languages.

DTIMEC(T(n))=‚ãÉA‚ààCDTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))=\bigcup_{A\in\mathcal C}DTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEC(T(n))=A‚ààC‚ãÉ‚ÄãDTIMEA(T(n))

Similarly we have DSPACEC(T(n))DSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))DSPACEC(T(n)), NTIMEC(T(n))NTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))NTIMEC(T(n)) and NSPACEC(T(n))NSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))NSPACEC(T(n)).

This again extends to all other complexity classes such as PNPP^{NP}PNP.

Turing Reductions

üìñDefinition 17 (Turing reductions). Let L1L_1L1‚Äã and L2L_2L2‚Äã be languages. We say that L1L_1L1‚Äã log-space Turing machine reduces to L2L_2L2‚Äã (L1‚â§Tlog‚Å°L2L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2L1‚Äã‚â§Tlog‚ÄãL2‚Äã), if L1‚ààLL2L_1\in L^{L_2}L1‚Äã‚ààLL2‚Äã. Similarly we say L1L_1L1‚Äã polynomial time Turing reduces to L2L_2L2‚Äã (L1‚â§TPL2L_1\le_T^PL_2L1‚Äã‚â§TP‚ÄãL2‚Äã), if L1‚ààPL2L_1\in P^{L_2}L1‚Äã‚ààPL2‚Äã.

It also satisfies transitivity.

ü§îLemma 2. Transitivity.

  • L1‚â§Tlog‚Å°L2,L2‚â§Tlog‚Å°L3‚áíL1‚â§Tlog‚Å°L3L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2,L_2\le_T^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{\log}L_3L1‚Äã‚â§Tlog‚ÄãL2‚Äã,L2‚Äã‚â§Tlog‚ÄãL3‚Äã‚áíL1‚Äã‚â§Tlog‚ÄãL3‚Äã
  • L1‚â§TPL2,L2‚â§TPL3‚áíL1‚â§TPL3L_1\le_T^{P}L_2,L_2\le_T^{P}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{P}L_3L1‚Äã‚â§TP‚ÄãL2‚Äã,L2‚Äã‚â§TP‚ÄãL3‚Äã‚áíL1‚Äã‚â§TP‚ÄãL3‚Äã

ü§îProposition 3. The class L,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under log-space Turing reductions. The class P,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under polynomial-time Turing machine.

The Polynomial-time Hierarchy via Oracles and Quantifiers

For a class of language C\mathcal CC, denote coCco\mathcal CcoC the class of complements of languages of C\mathcal CC.

coC={L‚Äæ‚à£L‚ààC}co\mathcal C=\{\overline L|L\in\mathcal C\}coC={L‚à£L‚ààC}

üìñDefinition 18 (polynomial-time hierarchy). Let Œî0P=Œ£0P=Œ†0P=P\Delta_0^P=\Sigma_0^P=\Pi_0^P=PŒî0P‚Äã=Œ£0P‚Äã=Œ†0P‚Äã=P. For i‚â•0i\ge0i‚â•0, define further Œîi+1P=PŒ£iP\Delta_{i+1}^P=P^{\Sigma_i^P}Œîi+1P‚Äã=PŒ£iP‚Äã, Œ£i+1P=NPŒ£iP\Sigma_{i+1}^P=NP^{\Sigma_i^P}Œ£i+1P‚Äã=NPŒ£iP‚Äã and Œ†i+1P=coNPŒ£iP\Pi_{i+1}^P=coNP^{\Sigma_i^P}Œ†i+1P‚Äã=coNPŒ£iP‚Äã. Finally, let Polynomial Hierarchy PH=‚ãÉi‚â•0Œ£iPPH=\bigcup_{i\ge0}\Sigma_i^PPH=‚ãÉi‚â•0‚ÄãŒ£iP‚Äã.

The classes ŒîiP,Œ£iP,Œ†iP\Delta_i^P,\Sigma_i^P,\Pi_i^PŒîiP‚Äã,Œ£iP‚Äã,Œ†iP‚Äã are said to make up level iii of the polynomial-time hierarchy, and PHPHPH denotes the entire polynomial-time hierarchy.

Note that Œî1P=PP=P\Delta_1^P=P^P=PŒî1P‚Äã=PP=P, Œ£1P=NPP=NP\Sigma_1^P=NP^P=NPŒ£1P‚Äã=NPP=NP, Œ†1P=coNPP=coNP\Pi_1^P=coNP^P=coNPŒ†1P‚Äã=coNPP=coNP.

On second level, we have PNP,NPNP,coNPNPP^{NP}, NP^{NP}, coNP^{NP}PNP,NPNP,coNPNP, continuing ad infimum.

Straightforward:

ŒîiP‚äÜŒ£iP‚à©Œ†iP‚äÜŒ£iP‚à™Œ†iP‚äÜŒîi+1P\Delta_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cap\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cup\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Delta_{i+1}^PŒîiP‚Äã‚äÜŒ£iP‚Äã‚à©Œ†iP‚Äã‚äÜŒ£iP‚Äã‚à™Œ†iP‚Äã‚äÜŒîi+1P‚Äã

üéØTheorem 27. PH‚äÜPSPACEPH\subseteq PSPACEPH‚äÜPSPACE.

Using polynomial space simply simulate the non-deterministic Turing machine same way as in proof of Theorem 10.

Then prove an equivalent definition of the classes Œ£iP\Sigma_i^PŒ£iP‚Äã and Œ†iP\Pi_i^PŒ†iP‚Äã in terms of quantifiers.

üéØTheorem 28. Let LLL be any language and let i‚â•1i\ge1i‚â•1. Then L‚ààŒ£iPL\in\Sigma_i^PL‚ààŒ£iP‚Äã iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L‚Ä≤‚ààŒ†i‚àí1PL'\in\Pi_{i-1}^PL‚Ä≤‚ààŒ†i‚àí1P‚Äã s.t.

\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist y:|y|\le q(|x|)\and\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].

Áúã‰∏çÊáÇ‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

ü§îCorollary 3. Let LLL be any language and let i‚â•1i\ge1i‚â•1. Then L‚ààŒ†iPL\in\Pi_i^PL‚ààŒ†iP‚Äã iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L‚Ä≤‚ààŒ£i‚àí1PL'\in\Sigma_{i-1}^PL‚Ä≤‚ààŒ£i‚àí1P‚Äã s.t.

‚àÄx:[x‚ààL‚áî‚àÄy:‚à£y‚à£‚â§q(‚à£x‚à£)‚áí‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤].\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall y:|y|\le q(|x|)\Rarr\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].‚àÄx:[x‚ààL‚áî‚àÄy:‚à£y‚à£‚â§q(‚à£x‚à£)‚áí‚ü®x,y‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤].

ü§îCorollary 4. Let LLL be any language and let i‚â•1i\ge1i‚â•1. Then L‚ààŒ£iPL\in\Sigma_i^PL‚ààŒ£iP‚Äã iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L‚Ä≤‚ààPL'\in PL‚Ä≤‚ààP s.t.

‚àÄx:[x‚ààL‚áî‚àÉqy1‚àÄqy2‚ãØQiqyi:‚ü®x,y1,y2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,yi‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist^qy_1\forall^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],‚àÄx:[x‚ààL‚áî‚àÉqy1‚Äã‚àÄqy2‚Äã‚ãØQiq‚Äãyi‚Äã:‚ü®x,y1‚Äã,y2‚Äã,‚ãØ,yi‚Äã‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤],

where QiQ_iQi‚Äã is ‚àÉ\exist‚àÉ if iii is odd, and ‚àÄ\forall‚àÄ if iii is even. Likewise, L‚ààŒ†iPL\in\Pi_i^PL‚ààŒ†iP‚Äã iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L‚Ä≤‚ààPL'\in PL‚Ä≤‚ààP s.t.

‚àÄx:[x‚ààL‚áî‚àÄqy1‚àÉqy2‚ãØQiqyi:‚ü®x,y1,y2,‚ãØ‚Äâ,yi‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall^qy_1\exist^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],‚àÄx:[x‚ààL‚áî‚àÄqy1‚Äã‚àÉqy2‚Äã‚ãØQiq‚Äãyi‚Äã:‚ü®x,y1‚Äã,y2‚Äã,‚ãØ,yi‚Äã‚ü©‚ààL‚Ä≤],

where QiQ_iQi‚Äã is ‚àÉ\exist‚àÉ if iii is even, and ‚àÄ\forall‚àÄ if iii is odd.

Generalize whether P=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNP to question whether ŒîiP=Œ£iP,Œ£iP=Œ†iP\Delta_i^P=\Sigma_i^P,\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PŒîiP‚Äã=Œ£iP‚Äã,Œ£iP‚Äã=Œ†iP‚Äã for i>1i\gt1i>1.

üéØTheorem 29. If Œ£iP=Œ†iP\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PŒ£iP‚Äã=Œ†iP‚Äã for some i‚â•1i\ge1i‚â•1 then PH=Œ£iPPH=\Sigma_i^PPH=Œ£iP‚Äã.

ÁªßÁª≠Áúã Â§©‰π¶„ÄÇ

Completeness in the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

Œ£iSAT\Sigma_iSATŒ£i‚ÄãSAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables œà=‚àÉx1‚àÄx2‚ãØQixiœÜ(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xi)\psi=\exist x_1\forall x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)œà=‚àÉx1‚Äã‚àÄx2‚Äã‚ãØQi‚Äãxi‚ÄãœÜ(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xi‚Äã), where xj‚àà{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xj‚Äã‚àà{0,1}nj‚Äã for all jjj and Qi=‚àÄQ_i=\forallQi‚Äã=‚àÄ for even iii and ‚àÉ\exist‚àÉ for odd iii.

Question: Is œà\psiœà true?

Œ†iSAT\Pi_iSATŒ†i‚ÄãSAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables œà=‚àÄx1‚àÉx2‚ãØQixiœÜ(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xi)\psi=\forall x_1\exist x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)œà=‚àÄx1‚Äã‚àÉx2‚Äã‚ãØQi‚Äãxi‚ÄãœÜ(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xi‚Äã), where xj‚àà{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xj‚Äã‚àà{0,1}nj‚Äã for all jjj and Qi=‚àÄQ_i=\forallQi‚Äã=‚àÄ for odd iii and ‚àÉ\exist‚àÉ for even iii.

Question: Is œà\psiœà true?

üéØTheorem 30. Œ£iSAT\Sigma_iSATŒ£i‚ÄãSAT is complete for Œ£iP\Sigma_i^PŒ£iP‚Äã and Œ†iSAT\Pi_iSATŒ†i‚ÄãSAT is complete for Œ†iP\Pi_i^PŒ†iP‚Äã.

ÂâçÈù¢ÁöÑÊé®ËÆ∫ 4 ÈÉΩÊ≤°ÊáÇ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶Ëøô‰∏™ËØÅÊòéÂ∞±Êõ¥‰∏çÊáÇ‰∫Ü

In case of Qi=‚àÉQ_i=\existQi‚Äã=‚àÉ, we ended up with a CNF formula œÜ\varphiœÜ.

In case of Qi=‚àÄQ_i=\forallQi‚Äã=‚àÄ, we ended up with a DNF formula œÜ\varphiœÜ.

üéØTheorem 31. If PHPHPH has a complete language, then PHPHPH collapses.

This follows since PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE has complete problems.

Collapses Âú®Ê≠§Â§ÑÊåáÂ§öÈ°πÂºèÂ±ÇÊ¨°ÁªìÊûÑ‰∏≠Êüê‰∏ÄÂ±Ç‰ª•‰∏äÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÁ∫ßÂà´ÈÉΩÈáçÂêàÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ„ÄÇ

The Karp-Lipton Theorem

A possible way to prove P‚â†NPP\neq NPPÓÄ†=NP would be to show that there is some language in NPNPNP that is not computed by a family of polynomial size Boolean circuits, i.e., that NP‚äÜÃ∏P/polyNP\not\subseteq P/polyNPÓÄ†‚äÜP/poly.

This is stronger than P‚â†NPP\neq NPPÓÄ†=NP since P‚äÜP/polyP\subseteq P/polyP‚äÜP/poly. It turns out that it is not stronger than the assumption that the polynomial-time hierarchy does not collapse.

üéØTheorem 32. Suppose that NP‚äÜP/polyNP\subseteq P/polyNP‚äÜP/poly. Then PH=Œ£2P‚à©Œ†2PPH=\Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PPH=Œ£2P‚Äã‚à©Œ†2P‚Äã.

Proof by Theorem 29, Corollary 4.

entry.title: ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂíåËÆ°ÁÆóÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶ 4 Reductions and Completeness
entry.content:
Reductions

NP-completeness: by polynomial-time many-one reductions (aka Karp reductions)

Studying completeness of P and NL: by log-space many-one reduction. Also too powerful for completeness inside L.

üìñDefinition 14 (Log-space reductions). Let L1‚äÜŒ£1‚àóL_1\subseteq\Sigma_1^*L1‚Äã‚äÜŒ£1‚àó‚Äã and L2‚äÜŒ£2‚àóL_2\subseteq\Sigma_2^*L2‚Äã‚äÜŒ£2‚àó‚Äã be languages. A log-space many-one reduction from L1L_1L1‚Äã to L2L_2L2‚Äã is a function f:Œ£1‚àó‚ÜíŒ£2‚àóf:\Sigma_1^*\rarr\Sigma_2^*f:Œ£1‚àó‚Äã‚ÜíŒ£2‚àó‚Äã s.t.

  1. There exists a log-space Turing machine computing fff.
  2. For all x‚ààŒ£1‚àóx\in\Sigma_1^*x‚ààŒ£1‚àó‚Äã, we have x‚ààL1‚áîf(x)‚ààL2x\in L_1\Lrarr f(x)\in L_2x‚ààL1‚Äã‚áîf(x)‚ààL2‚Äã.

Denote: L1‚â§mlog‚Å°L2L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2L1‚Äã‚â§mlog‚ÄãL2‚Äã

The definition of polynomial-time many-one reduction (L1‚â§mpL2L_1\le_m^pL_2L1‚Äã‚â§mp‚ÄãL2‚Äã) is similar (simply using polynomial-time Turing machine instead).

üìñDefinition 15 (‚â§mlog‚Å°\le_m^{\log}‚â§mlog‚Äã-hard/complete). Let LLL be a language and C\mathcal CC be a class of languages. We say that LLL is ‚â§mlog‚Å°\le_m^{\log}‚â§mlog‚Äã-hard for C\mathcal CC if for every L‚Ä≤‚ààCL'\in\mathcal CL‚Ä≤‚ààC we have L‚Ä≤‚â§mlog‚Å°LL'\le_m^{\log}LL‚Ä≤‚â§mlog‚ÄãL. We say LLL is ‚â§mlog‚Å°\le_m^{\log}‚â§mlog‚Äã-complete if we additionally have L‚ààCL\in\mathcal CL‚ààC.

Reduction has property of transitivity.

ü§îLemma 1. L1‚â§mlog‚Å°L2,L2‚â§mlog‚Å°L3‚áíL1‚â§mlog‚Å°L3L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2, L_2\le_m^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_m^{\log}L_3L1‚Äã‚â§mlog‚ÄãL2‚Äã,L2‚Äã‚â§mlog‚ÄãL3‚Äã‚áíL1‚Äã‚â§mlog‚ÄãL3‚Äã.

Let M1M_1M1‚Äã and M2M_2M2‚Äã be log-space Turing machines computing f1:L1‚ÜíL2,f2:L2‚ÜíL3f_1:L_1\to L_2,f_2:L_2\to L_3f1‚Äã:L1‚Äã‚ÜíL2‚Äã,f2‚Äã:L2‚Äã‚ÜíL3‚Äã, respectively. It suffices to show that f=f2‚àòf1f=f_2\circ f_1f=f2‚Äã‚àòf1‚Äã is computable by log-space Turing machine MMM.

On input xxx, we simulate M2M_2M2‚Äã with virtual input tape f1(x)f_1(x)f1‚Äã(x). We maintain a counter giving the position of the virtual input tape head of M2M_2M2‚Äã. To simulate step of computation of M2M_2M2‚Äã, we start simulating M1M_1M1‚Äã on input xxx, counting and then discarding the output symbols by M1M_1M1‚Äã until the output symbol where the virtual input tape head is placed is to be written. Then the step of M2M_2M2‚Äã can be complete.

Let xxx be of length n=‚à£n‚à£n=|n|n=‚à£n‚à£. ‚à£f(x)‚à£=2O(log‚Å°n)=nO(1)|f(x)|=2^{O(\log n)}=n^{O(1)}‚à£f(x)‚à£=2O(logn)=nO(1), storing the position of the virtual tape head as well as the work tapes of M1M_1M1‚Äã and M2M_2M2‚Äã takes space O(log‚Å°n)O(\log n)O(logn).

ÊàëËßâÂæó‰πüÊå∫ÊòæÁÑ∂ÁöÑÂëÄÔºåÁî®‰∏§Âè∞ÂØπÊï∞Á©∫Èó¥ÁöÑÂõæÁÅµÊú∫Ê®°ÊãüÔºåÊÄªÁ©∫Èó¥‰ªçÁÑ∂ÊòØÂØπÊï∞ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

Then we define reduction ‚™Ø\preceq‚™Ø between languages.

üìñDefinition 16. A language LLL is hard for C\mathcal CC under ‚™Ø\preceq‚™Ø reductions if for all L‚Ä≤‚ààCL'\in\mathcal CL‚Ä≤‚ààC we have L‚Ä≤‚™ØLL'\preceq LL‚Ä≤‚™ØL. A language LLL is complete for C\mathcal CC under ‚™Ø\preceq‚™Ø reductions if L‚ààCL\in\mathcal CL‚ààC in addition to begin hard for C\mathcal CC under ‚™Ø\preceq‚™Ø reductions.

Complexity class has an important property: the complexity class is closed under reductions.

We say C\mathcal CC is closed w.r.t. ‚™Ø\preceq‚™Ø reductions, if whenever L‚Ä≤‚™ØLL'\preceq LL‚Ä≤‚™ØL and L‚ààCL\in\mathcal CL‚ààC, we also have L‚Ä≤‚ààCL'\in CL‚Ä≤‚ààC. Proof omitted.

ü§îProposition 2. The classes L,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under log-space many-one reductions. The classes P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under polynomial-time many-one reductions.

NL-completeness

The basic NL-complete problem is given by connectivity in a directed graph (STCONSTCONSTCON).

STCON

The instance: Directed graph DDD and nodes sss and ttt.

Question: Is there a directed path in DDD from sss to ttt?

üéØTheorem 20. STCONSTCONSTCON is complete for NL.

A non-deterministic log-space Turing machine can guess a path from sss to ttt one node at a time, reusing space.

To show NL-hardness, Let L‚ààNLL\in NLL‚ààNL be accepted by non-deterministic log-space Turing machine MMM.

Given input xxx s.t. MMM accepts xxx iff there is a path in the configuration graph of MMM on input xxx from the initial configuration to an accepting configuration.

A log-space reduction from LLL to STCONSTCONSTCON is:

On input xxx we generate all configurations of MMM on input xxx, which then forms the set of nodes together with an additional node ttt. Initial configuration becomes the node sss.

Next generate all arcs between configurations corresponding to a single step of the Turing machine and finally arcs between all accepting configurations to the new node ttt. We then have that the resulting directed graph DDD has a path from sss to ttt iff MMM accepts xxx.

By Savitch‚Äôs Theorem and Immerman-Szelepcs√©nyi Theorem, STCON‚ààDSPACE(log‚Å°2n)STCON\in DSPACE(\log^2n)STCON‚ààDSPACE(log2n) and STCON‚Äæ‚ààNL\overline{STCON}\in NLSTCON‚ààNL, respectively.

P/NP-completeness

Basic PPP and NPNPNP-complete problems are given by the ability of Boolean circuits to simulate Turing machines on fixed input length. For PPP this gives the circuit value problem.

CVP problem

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs and input x‚àà{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx‚àà{0,1}n.

Question: Is C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

üéØTheorem 21. CVPCVPCVP is complete for PPP.

SAT problem

CircuitSAT

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs

Question: Does there exist x‚àà{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx‚àà{0,1}n s.t. C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

üéØTheorem 22. CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT is complete for NPNPNP.

Let me use Chinese

‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πà CircuitSAT Â±û‰∫é NPNPNP„ÄÇÁÆÄÂçïÁêÜËß£Â∞±ÊòØÈùûÁ°ÆÂÆöÊÄßÂõæÁÅµÊú∫ NTM ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Â§öÈ°πÂºèÊó∂Èó¥Ëß£ÂÜ≥Ê≠§ÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÊÄùÊÉ≥Â∞±ÊòØÊö¥ÂäõÊûö‰∏æÔºå‰∏ÄÂÖ±ÈÅçÂéÜ 2n2^n2n Ê¨°„ÄÇËøôÊ†∑Âú®Á°ÆÂÆöÊÄßÂõæÁÅµÊú∫ DTM ‰∏äÁ°ÆÂÆûÂ∞±ÊòØ O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂú®ÈùûÁ°ÆÂÆöÊÄßÂõæÁÅµÊú∫‰∏äÔºåÂ∞±ÂéâÂÆ≥‰∫Ü„ÄÇÈíàÂØπÊØè‰∏Ä‰ΩçÔºåÈùûÁ°ÆÂÆöÊÄßÂõæÁÅµÊú∫ÂèØ‰ª•ÂêåÊó∂ÁåúÊµã 000 Âíå 111ÔºåËøôÊ†∑‰∏ÄÂÖ±ÈÅçÂéÜ nnn Ê¨°ÂàÜÂà´ÂØπÂ∫î nnn ‰ΩçÔºåÂ∞±ÂæóÂà∞‰∫Ü NPNPNP ÁöÑÁªìÊûú„ÄÇ

As for NPNPNP-hard, construct language L‚ààNTIME(nk)L\in NTIME(n^k)L‚ààNTIME(nk) for k>0k\gt0k>0.

‚Ä¶

SAT

Instance: CNF formula œÜ\varphiœÜ.

Question: Does œÜ\varphiœÜ have a satisfying assigment?

üéØTheorem 23. CNF satisfiability problem is also complete for NPNPNP.

It‚Äôs easy to see SAT‚ààNPSAT\in NPSAT‚ààNP.

For hardness, by reduction from CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT.

PSPACE-completeness

Basic PSPACE-completeness is given by the problem of deciding validity of true quantified Boolean formulas as shown by Stockmeyer and Meyer. (TQBFTQBFTQBF)

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variable œà=Q1x1Q2x2‚ãØQnxnœÜ(x1,‚ãØ‚Äâ,xn)\psi=Q_1x_1Q_2x_2\cdots Q_nx_n\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)œà=Q1‚Äãx1‚ÄãQ2‚Äãx2‚Äã‚ãØQn‚Äãxn‚ÄãœÜ(x1‚Äã,‚ãØ,xn‚Äã), where Qi‚àà{‚àÄ,‚àÉ}Q_i\in\{\forall,\exist\}Qi‚Äã‚àà{‚àÄ,‚àÉ} and xi‚àà{0,1}x_i\in\{0,1\}xi‚Äã‚àà{0,1} for all iii.

EXP/NEXP-completeness

Consider so-called succinct versions of complete problems of PPP and NPNPNP.

Let CCC be a Boolean circuit with nnn input gates and one output gate. The truthtable of CCC is the string tt(C)‚àà{0,1}2ntt(C)\in\{0,1\}^{2^n}tt(C)‚àà{0,1}2n giving the evaluation of CCC on all possible inputs.

Then define the succinct version SuccinctLSuccinctLSuccinctL of LLL simply by SuccinctL={C‚à£tt(C)‚ààL}SuccinctL=\{C|tt(C)\in L\}SuccinctL={C‚à£tt(C)‚ààL}. Note that when L‚ààPL\in PL‚ààP we have that SuccinctL‚ààEXPSuccinctL\in EXPSuccinctL‚ààEXP simply by decompressing the input CCC to tt(C)tt(C)tt(C) in exponential time and then using the polynomial-time Turing machine to check for membership in LLL.
